description:
One of my favorite places in all of San Francisco. I can't believe anyone would compare this magnificent food truck to a 7/11, or take off a star because it's a popular place and has a long line.

Get the chicken katsu curry for nine bucks (at least 3 spice) and experience the tastiest Japanese curry in the city.

If you're concerned about standing outside for 10 minutes, order ahead on Yelp!
author: Kedar V.

description:
Every Thursday, around 12:25 PM, right as my first fork of pork katsu curry enters my mouth, I get to experience true happiness. 

I'm a complete wimp when it comes to spicy food, so the mild curry is what I go with. I don't do the extra pickles nor the vegetables. The original order has the perfect combination of food and flavor to leave me feeling completely satisfied with my meal. Coming in at a total of $9.77, this is probably the best food you're going to find in the city for its price. 
What's more is the consistency. I've never been disappointed or felt that something was 'off'. 

People don't go because they complain about long lines, and I don't blame them. I always just order online through Yelp and repeat my past order. That's about 4 clicks and 2 minutes of waiting at the actual truck (just to flag the guy in the back and tell him that I'm there). 

A spot will always be open for Japacurry on my Thursday afternoons, in my stomach, and in my heart.
author: Jatin N.

description:
This place always has a long line, but the line moves kinda quickly and it's worth it.

The bento boxes are fantastic but you have to arrive kinda early to get one before they sell out. I go with the BBQ Beef if they still have it. Lots of great flavor, a good amount of beef and rice, you can't go wrong. Though they aren't warm if that makes a difference to you.

If they've ran out of beef bento by the time I get there, I typically get sausage curry or chicken curry. Not as flavorful as the bento boxes but they're more fresh.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Quick and friendly service. I decided to try their daily special bento instead of their popular curry dishes and I'm happy that I did. The daily bento comes with salmon, half of a potato croquette, rice, wakame, pieces of chicken and pork karaage, gyoza, egg roll, and more. All was fresh, bright, and flavorful. I love variety, so this was definitely for me. 

If you're not into sampling and want a heartier meal, go with the curries.
author: Lori C.

description:
The chicken karaage curry was pretty good! The chicken was juicy and they give you the curry sauce on the side so you can pour as much or as little as you'd like over everything.

I arrived at the JapaCurry truck around 12pm noon, which was kind of a bad idea because that's when everyone goes on their lunch break. Had to wait a while to pay and to get my food. I recommend going around 12:30pm if you can so you can avoid the long wait times.
author: Wesley S.

description:
Solid lunch option and always filling for when you're feeling hungry.  Dependent on the day of the week, it's located in different parts of downtown SF.  Not quite sure where they are on Tuesday's, but on Thursday's, they're on Mission and New Montgomery!

Pork katsu with medium spicy (5x) curry and extra veggies is always my go to order.  The pumpkin croquette too if I'm feeling a little extra.  The breading's always nice and crispy with plenty of flavor without being overcooked.  They're consistently good even though they're always so busy.  The pumpkin croquette is on the sweeter side, so I'd avoid it if you're not a fan of sweets - but I like it!  Crispy on the outside, sweet pumpkin on the inside!

There's always a line, but if you want to beat the rush, I'd recommend getting to the food truck by 11:30 PM otherwise you're going to be a very long queue.
author: Carena N.

description:
Making my way downtown on Sansome St. (walking fast, faces pass and I'm homebound.. dun dun dun dun)

And I stumble upon this beauty!

I've heard of the name just a couple times so once I saw it, immediately I ordered their Katsu Curry ($9 + tax) a bag will cost you $.25

Totally recommend if you stumble upon this to order from here, definitely bang for your buck and unsure where you'll stumble upon it again.. speaking of which

I found this truck on Sansome St. on a Monday after Pine St. and before Transamerica between the timeframe of 1:15pm to 1:35pm if my memory serves me correctly...

But nonetheless, good luck LOL
author: Yeanne L.

description:
We waited in the line for at least 30 minutes before it was our turn. I ordered their chicken katsu curry, looking at how many ppl actually in the line made me believe that their curry was somehow magical but in fact it was just like those ordinary microwaveable curry u could get at 711 in Asia. 

They only gave u half a bowl of curry sauce but I think it is sufficient. The chicken katsu wasn't that amazing, it is just lots of breading on a normal piece of chicken. honestly I am not really sure why it is such a hype. The only highlight of this dish is the ginger, it is amazing when u stir it in the rice. It is kinda sad that I find the only element that shines in a meaty curry dish is ginger. And I prob not gonna go back anymore. And if u r just a tourist in town and see there is a huge line, just skip it. Don't try it, it is not worth the wait. If u see no line, and u r hungry, do it. Cuz why not?
author: Shuang W.

description:
This truck comes to our area every Thursday. It's really convenient and the food is great. I tried the Chicken  
Katsu Curry last time, and the KUROBUTA Sausage Curry this time. I love them both and going to try others on their menu.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
Brilliant rice and curry!

Went here on a weekday around lunch. There was a pretty long line (5-10 mins) and the food justifies the line. Got the tofu katsu curry with rice. The tofu was breaded and soft, and went brilliantly with the curry. The curry is brilliant - high on flavor, not too heavy.

Service is quick too and there's a nice open space nearby to sit and eat at. Def a terrific place for a quick takeout!
author: Vignesh B.

description:
I came here for lunch because a few weeks ago I saw a super long line in front of this truck and thought it must be popular. It was parked near Mission and 2nd. 

[ Teriyaki Chicken Bento ] I was in a rush so I got a pre-made bento box to avoid the line. However, I think this truck must be famous for its curry. I did not enjoy the bento box because it was very bland. The veggies had no flavor at all and the teriyaki chicken was very mediocre. However, presentation of the box was beautiful.
author: Annie Z.

description:
6 stars: If I could pick one thing to eat before I die, I would pick a chicken katsu japacurry, medium spicy, add vegetables. I have eaten here every week for the last 7 years and have been impressed every single time. The chicken is so moist and tender, with the breading very crispy and flavorful. The curry has a rich flavor and is thickened by slowly cooked onions. Most currries use potatoes, which make it too thick, but japacurry does not use potatoes. Japacurry may be the one thing I'll defend to my death (the chicken is significantly better than Muracci's). I'm going to go get it today. If you're in financial district for lunch, you should too. 

Locations: 
Mon and Fri: Sansome and California
Tues and Wed: Howard and 1st
Thurs: Mission and New Montgomery 

Pro-tip: add vegetables (broccoli, cauliflower, carrots) for $1 to feel healthier. There's also a stamp reward card.
author: Jason Y.

description:
The lines are usually very long at peak lunch time so definitely order take out on Yelp and swing by to pick it up to save time ;)

I've gotten the pumpkin croquette curry and a bento box before. The bento box was nice if you like to try a wide variety of small bites. The food was ok, but they are definitely more known for the curry. Won't be getting it again. But the pumpkin croquette was really delicious. It was very sweet. Kinda sad that you only get one though. The portion size is on the smaller end. Would love it if they sold the pumpkin croquette as a side.

Can't wait to try the katsu curry next time.

Also a mild is more like "not spicy"
author: Jenny J.

description:
If you're even reading this review, someone at your office has told you about the supposed "greatest Japanese curry [they've] had since coming back from Tokyo a few years ago'. And while I wouldn't go quite that far, they're definitely onto something. It's the runnier sort rather than the thicker kind you might get from a Golden Curry box, but that's not a knock against it. It makes it easier to eat with the rice, and the flavor is rich and satisfying. The katsu is always the perfect crisp, yet soft and moist texture, and adding a few levels of spicy gives it a good kick that plays well off the tsukemono.

It's reasonably-priced, damn tasty, and now you can skip the line by ordering ahead online! There's no reason not to go, really, and this place and Halal Cart consistently jockey for the top spot on my "I spent a lot of money last weekend, let's get some cheap-ish but still delicious food" lunch list.

Also, they finally take card too!
author: Shawn W.

description:
Ran into this truck while running around town.  We tried the curry, the chicken katsu, and the spicy version as well with the chicken karaage.  

I can't say I was blown away by the flavors.  The curry was on the sweet side so if you are really craving sweet curry, this is the place to be.  The downside is that I never got vegetables on any of the curry bowls.  I thought that was apart of it.  So we got a bunch of rice with a bowl of curry on the side.
author: Julie C.

description:
JapaCurry! I've seen this truck pretty frequently, but never stopped by until today.

I got the Pork Katsu Curry (Spicy) and a pumpkin croquette on the side. It came in a take-out box with rice and pork katsu, and a soup take-out container with curry and some pickled vegetables.

As someone who enjoys spicy food, I didn't think it was that spicy (They sprinkle some ground pepper flakes on top). The curry was nice and thick, but wasn't filled with a lot of solids, mostly liquified potato, from what I could tell. The flavor was really nice, and the warmth really satisfying especially on the cold day that I ate this on.

Pumpkin Croquette was alright, not amazing; very crispy and tasted like pumpkin, just like one would expect.

I think my one gripe about the food is that the rice got stuck to the sides of the take-out container, and took more effort than expected to extract from the container.

Overall, very satisfied with the taste of Japacurry's Pork Katsu Curry, and I want to come here again sometime to try their other menu options!
author: Ed W.

description: The karage curry or the chicken katsu rice and curry are very good. Definitely worth a try.
author: Sunil R.

description: This place is pretty good. The prices are very reasonable and the portion is perfect. They might as well just save me the two blocks walk from the office and park right in front because it seems everyone in the office goes here on Thursday. Saying our office loves this place would be an understatement. It might be more profitable from a productivity perspective for our company to just buy the truck rather than effectively pay every employee to wait in the line every Thursday. The math is surprisingly close on that one. So yeah, it's pretty good.
author: Eric L.

description:
I feel like EVERYONE at my company goes here for lunch on Thursdays. The JapaCurry Truck is right around the corner from our office. So I decided I had to try it one day to see what all the fuss was about. 

I went on a Thursday and pro tip you can order right from the Yelp app and skip the line! Because most of the time during lunch rush, there is a huge line and you will wait and wait and then be sad that your lunch break is over by the time you get your food. That doesn't speak to them being slow, the staff is quite speedy and efficient, there will just be that many people ordering and standing in line and also those that have ordered online. Also, if you order through the app you can use your card, I think they only accept cash at the truck! 

I ordered the chicken katsu curry and decided to add the veggies. I did ask for them to make it spicy, and boy oh boy it was spicy but still very good. The curry has a really nice flavor and has a nice consistency. The chicken was nicely fried and everything was super hot and fresh. Overall, it was a good lunch, honestly I still don't really see what all the hype is about but it was good.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
JapaCurry has become my go to lunch spot on Thursdays over the last couple of months. Their food trucks are located all over the city but I usually head to the one on Mission and New Montgomery every Thursday. 

I usually order either the Chicken Karaage or the Katsu Chicken with brown rice and extra curry. To really appreciate the food here, make sure you go for the spicy version of the curry and level up to something like 4X at the very least. It's not a JapaCurry experience if you don't have tears rolling down your face while you are smiling because of the delicious meal! 

A couple of things to note: Always pre-order on Yelp or be prepared to wait in line for 20 minutes and pay by cash.
author: Gaurav K.

description:
I love this place! And the best part is how convenient it is, just a block away from my office. Their service is very fast (even though the lines are long, if you don't want to wait come @ 11:45am!!), and the katsu is always crunchy. 

Even though Muracci's is still my favorite curry place in SF, Japacurry is still very very good!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
They serve some really good Chicken Katsu.
The line is really long on weekdays for lunch between 12-1. Order online on yelp! he portion size is pretty big - both the meat as well as the curry. The pork katsu has less meat than chicken katsu - but looks like my coworkers are fine with the tradeoff. There are a few levels of spicy - its basically the red chili powder they add on top of curry. Its also cash only (Except when ordering online) - BUT if you give them a wide smile and an innocent look, they will take your credit card if you dont carry cash like me.
Another tip - If you dip each bite of chicken+rice into the curry instead of pouring the curry all over - it tastes better!
author: Arjan N.

description: Great Japanese curry! As good as Murracci's except they're in a truck. They're on Howard street every Tues and Wed which is convenient for us to drop by. Arrive early (11.30am) or late (1.00pm-1.30pm) so you don't have to wait.
author: Thomas C.

description:
JapaCurry is awesome! I almost always order the Chicken Katsu Curry with extra vegetables, which comes out to $10. The extra vegetables are cauliflower, carrot and broccoli cooked very al dente. I also love those pickled red things that come with it. Their croquettes are delicious as well.

The curry sauce is so so good. I take the spicy one and it is definitely manageable and not fire-breathing hot. 

I'm quite particular about my chicken. It needs to be mostly white meat and not stringy, which they deliver on. 

The line can be intimidating but it's worth it. Bring cash money!
author: Ellen H.

description: JapaCurry is the ultimate in Japanese lunch fare. I doubled down on a pork katsu curry ($9) + daily special bento ($10, highly recommended - it's definitely on par with Zen Izakaya's $10 bento box). I slightly regretted the amount of food I inhaled, but was also a very happy person upon finishing.  Good to the last bite.
author: Josh L.

description:
I'm a huge fan of JapaCurry but more for their not curry items. Don't get me wrong, their curry's pretty good as far as Japanese style curry goes but I just can't handle not having more veggies in my meal. (Yes I know you can add veggies but the veggies are plain, steamed, and just not interesting, so maybe just write me off as someone who doesn't like Japanese curry as a complete meal).

My favorite thing to get here is their Daily Bento Special (http://bit.ly/2r59S19). For just $10, you get a full box of delicious items (rice, veggies, fish). There's a lot of variety and everything's delicious! The serving size is fantastic as well. 

I've also had their Cold Ramen (http://bit.ly/2qENsDW) which had a tad bit more wasabi than I generally like but was still a very good meal for $9. Serving size wise it's a bit on the small end (compared to their curry/bentos). I enjoyed the flavors and loved the eggs. It's fantastic on a hot day. 

Everything here is cash only and be prepared for long lines if you're coming here for lunch on a weekday! Their bentos also sell out so you might have to head over a bit earlier to get one.
author: Lily L.

description:
I know EVERYONE is all about their curry, but I'm actually not a fan. If you look on their menu, they have non-curry bento boxes...including a Soba Bento!!!!! I LOVE SOBA!!!!!!! The cool noodles on a hot day, the stinging feeling of wasabi up your nose, etc. It usually comes with tofu and veggies, but I requested no tofu. It's actually a really filling bento box and it was great.

I also ordered a side of the Potato Croquette. It's pretty much a dessert if you ask me. It's sweet, fried well, and thick. Yummy.

Pro-tip! Order ahead of time on the Yelp Eat24 app so you skip the line! But you may not want to place the order for a future date/time. I ordered for 12:30pm, but the food was ready at 12:00pm. So it pretty much would just be sitting there if I hadn't gone earlier. Maybe call them or check your order status with Yelp Eat24.
author: Athena C.

description:
The curry was a little sweet IMO. 

The Chicken Kara-age was more like a KFC recipe rather than japanese-crispy-fried-potato-starch-soy-yumminess.

I do admit however the portion was great for $9, but I'd rather have small, chronic morsels than a lot of "just okay."

I'll stick to Muracci's for now...
author: John M.

description: Tried katsu curry here which was really delicious. The curry had perfect flavors and the chicken was fried just right. The only caveat being i didn't find the curry enough spicy which i expected ( this is the second time i have experienced something like this in San Francisco , maybe its SF thing only )
author: Sharad B.

description:
One of my favorite food trucks in SF! Quite cheap and amazing Japanese food. As far as I know, it comes on Mission st on Thursdays. If you want to avoid a LONG line, do go before 12. You'll still see about 20 people if you go before 12, it becomes really long after 12. 
I have had katsu curry and karaage curry. Both are pretty good! I'd like more gravy, I find the quantity of gravy a bit less than what I expect for my meal. Both both these dishes are quite tasty. Also, even though the line is long, they prepare and give you your order pretty quickly so that's a big plus!
author: Rahul D.

description: Woooo baby this truck is the best fo a simple and delicious go to during lunch in SOMA and now you can order ahead with Yelp . Catch me out on mission every Thursday for that sweet ass Katsu.
author: Chevail A.

description:
Very reasonable prices!
Food is beyond yummy and filling!

Not much else to say.
I default to the Kara-age curry with spicy level 3 and extra-vegetables and pickles.
author: Subrat M.

description:
You can skip the line if you just want a bento box. They have two vegetarian options: tofu katsu curry and croquette katsu curry. 

They also have a stamp card you can ask for and your 10th curry will be free. 

They are cash only. 

Based on the popularity I think it's safe to say they transform from food truck to cash transport car over the course of the lunch hour.
author: Jenny L.

description:
JapaCurry katsu curry is a staple dish in my office on Thursday. They park it nearby, at Mission and New Montgomery. The line is usually terribly long and they accept cash only. But it's worth the wait and the hassle.

Now this is definitely more "street food" version of what Japanese cuisine has to offer and it's packed with calories, but oh my! It tastes so good.

Pro-tip: if you wanna skip the line, just get a bento box.
author: Jakub S.

description: I bought a bento box in JapaCurry first time today. I chose the Nori-ben that has seaweed on the rice, and fried white fish and chikuwa. It's a typical lunch box menu in Japan. Their bento's taste is good, but it might not have enough volume for men. Also, if you go there at noon, they're crowded. Always they have many customers. I went there at 11:30am today. It was no line. I bought lunch quickly.
author: Yumiko H.

description: Simple, fast Japanese curry. The line isn't as long as it looks! Karaage curry was great; big meaty chunks of juicy fried chicken, but curry was a bit lacking in flavour. Good portion size as well.
author: Kevin N.

description: I really wanted to like this, but I just don't like my curries prepared with too much onion and this one seemed like one part curry sauce and nine parts onions.
author: Richard K.

description:
Got the katsu chicken curry. The curry has rich flavours and good fried chicken

Tip: Spicy is a not too spicy. Ask for the spice level specifically.
author: Kairav P.

description:
The curry is pretty good, but this review is really for the bento boxes. 

Really, there's not many places near FiDi that have authentic Japanese bento lunch boxes, and the JapaCurry truck is my favorite. Daily Special bento is my go-to; you will usually get 1 grilled fish item, 1-2 fried items (e.g. karaage, chicken nanban, or croquette), a braised/sukiyaki item, some vegetables, edamame, tamago, a bit of Japanese sausage, all for $10. Extremely filling, and everything tastes fresh (though room-temperature, a quick bake in the toaster oven does those fried foods wonders!). Definitely a step up from what you'd get at a grocery store or 7-11 in Japan. Check their Twitter (https://twitter.com/JapaCurry) to see what's being sold. 

It does sell out quite quickly though! The Daily Special is usually out by ~12:30. The Nori Bento is also quite good but not nearly as much quantity/variety for the price.
author: Ervin T.

description:
3 Ways to my heart:
1) Chicken
2) Katsu
3) Curry

3s spice level is just perfect for me. Don't mind waiting in the long lines. It's totally worth it. This is also my favorite food truck in SF downtown. A couple of times I've found the Chicken to be not crispy enough but overall JapaCurry is amazing!
author: Sagar S.

description: I go here every week on Thursday. This is probably one thing I look forward to every Thursday. Katsu curry with chicken is something to die for.  The lines are super long between 11.30-12.30. So we found that the best time go here would be after 12.30. The serve pretty fast once they r done with their eat24 orders. The other way I have avoided long lines here is my ordering on eat24.
author: Kalyani R.

description:
A friend and I visited the truck when it was parked on Mission in between 2nd and 3rd street. It was only 11:45, but there was already a long line of people waiting for their orders and about 8 people waiting to place their orders. 

They had pre-made bentos, which aren't curry, and curry dishes. The line moved relatively fast. The line to actually get your food once you ordered also moved pretty quickly. I ordered the tonkatsu curry mild and my friend ordered the chicken katsu curry. Both were $9.

They pack the curry in a little tub and I got a paper box with my rice, katsu (that sat on top of the rice), and a mini container of Japanese pickles. Yummmmm. The curry wasn't amazing. It was good. I was surprised at how hot and crispy my katsu was. 

There was enough food to make me full. For the price, it is one of the more affordable FiDi lunches you can get. And definitely different from the typical salad joints in the area. I will be back. 

Get there early so that there ins't a long line. Also, there is a sign that says that 1 person can only order 4 meals. It is also cash only.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
A yummy bento break is just what this Hawaii girl needed today! The San Francisco downtown lunch scene is full of salads and sandwiches, but all I ever want to eat is rice! Thankfully while trying to decide between a quinoa salad or a Chipotle burrito I happened to stumble upon the JapaCurry Truck. Bentos, curry and fried croquette? Hell yeah! It all looked pretty legit and I decided upon their daily bento special. My lunch buddy ordered their chicken karaage curry and rice. I added the pumpkin croquette and our total was $22. Cash only.

The order came out super quick and we went back to the office to eat. I've had probably a thousand bentos in my lifetime and this one I'd rank an 8/10. I liked the variety in vegetables, protein and textures. A perfect bento is a seriously beautiful thing to behold and consume, so it's not something I take lightly. If they had a higher quality rice and cooked the salmon with a little crispy skin that would have brought it to the next level. Still it was pretty darn good for $10!

I didn't try my friend's curry but it looked pretty good and he said it was very filling. Oh and that pumpkin croquette was bomb.com! You should definitely order it if you're a pumpkin fan. 5-stars for making me so happy on a day when a bento was just what the doctor ordered!
author: Emi H.

description:
What can I say? JapaCurry makes some decent Japanese curry.

The truck is super convenient for lunch during the work day. Lately they have been plagued by long lines, though. Regardless, the employees appear to do their best to get through the massive amount of orders in a reasonable amount of time. Ordering online makes the process a bit more manageable.
author: Grant S.

description:
This food truck is by far one of my top 3 favorites. 

I normally get a chicken katsu curry in medium. It's bomb af. If you have not tried this place out, you truly are missing out! I'm a fan of curry when its a bit on the creamier side. The portions are pretty decent for being in SF's FiDi too. Quick tip... order online, you get your order faster. I'm on a pretty tight schedule at work, so having the ability to order online is a major win for me.
author: Josephine C.

description:
Their curry is the bomb! My usual order: Chicken Katsu curry, 5S spice level, brown rice (5/5)
 
Something about their curry is addictive. I think it's the nostalgia that does it for me... the curry's flavor has traces of 'Maggi tastemaker' (ask any Indian what that is).... makes me drool!
author: Ram R.

description: This place is so good. Every time I'm in the area for lunch I make it a point to eat the pork cutlet curry. Omg. No regrets.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
I'm loving this curry truck!!! Their katsu is crispy even after 15-20 minutes stuffed in a box while walking back to my work place. They make it right then and there and it's delicious! I love the Spicy Pork Katsu Curry with Rice. Be sure to add the ginger with the curry! I didn't like ginger by itself and it totally surprised me after adding the ginger. It is absolutely delicious!!! :D I think I will eat there at least twice a week from now on, if I can.

It's only $9 for this yummy curry goodness. I go around 1pm, before 1:45pm (their closing time) to avoid the long wait. The wait looks long but THEY ARE QUICK! 1-10 in less than 5 minutes! *love*

Go try it for yourself! Look for their truck on their twitter! It changes because they are a food truck so check before you go!!! :)
author: Kimberly W.

description: This place is one of my favorites! Really good chicken, and the curry is delicious. It is a bit hard to find sometimes because the truck moves day to day, but their schedule is on their site. Order on Eat24 to skip the line.
author: Wyatt S.

description: Yummy Japanese curry! I am always looking for a good curry place and this truck has it. I got the katsu chicken curry and my friend got the karage chicken.  Both chickens tasted great and it was fried well respectively. Curry was flavorful and although the spicy wasn't spicy at all.  Portions are pretty good and both were about $9. It was busy in SF so we had to wait a bit. Otherwise I would eat at this truck again if I was craving curry.
author: Jesse C.

description:
My coworkers hit up this truck on a regular basis.  Awesome curry that is worth the wait. Don't let the line intimidate you, it moves reasonably fast. You can get extra curry, veggies, and sausages if you're feeling extra hungry, as well as a bunch of other addons. There's also vegetarian/vegan options with tofu katsu and pumpkin coquette. 

The spiciness level of the curry is based on the amount of chili powder they add. A "3S" is spicy, "6S" is extra spicy, and the scale goes up to 10 so beware. Personally "5S" is the right spice level for me, you get strong heat but it's not punishing. 

Bento boxes are available as well, and can be purchased directly with no wait, which allows you to skip the curry line.
author: Han C.

description: Really long line for the famous JapaCurry Truck. I got the Pork Katsu. Very good. Very cripsy but the breading to meat ratio was a little high for me eat should always be the highlight!). A little more meat would be wonderful. You can get the curry regular or spicy. If you like spicy, definitely get it because it adds to the flavor well!
author: Kyle R.

description:
good simple curry for a pretty reasonable lunch price. The line moves quickly even though they get supermarket at lunchtime.

They pack the curry separate from the rice and put the katsu on top so it stays crispy. and generous with the pickles too.

Pro tip: order via Eat24 while you're walking over and you can skip the line.
author: Jimming C.

description:
I still always get excited whenever I see the JapaCurry Truck.  It's probably because they hardly ever come down to the peninsula anymore.  So now when I'm walking around downtown SF and spot that curry orange colored truck, I almost never hesitate to stop over for some curry.

I'm basically writing this update because it's been a while since my last review, and it's about a couple of menu items that weren't on the menu back then.

Karaage Curry w/ brown rice -- http://bit.ly/1T5wIdu
I've had this many times since they added this to their menu.  They use huge pieces of Chicken Karaage and they still give a good amount of curry to pour on top.  I also like how they have the option to have brown rice as well.

Okonomiyaki -- http://bit.ly/1T5wJy6
I tried this at the Nihonmachi Festival one year and they did a good job with it.  The one they served me was loaded with seafood and veggies.  It was pretty much as good as any okonomiyaki should be.  I hope they add it to their regular menu someday.

I've also tried their Curry Sandwich which was almost like a fried croquette filled with curry.  It was a good sized sandwich.  Very delicious and for about $5 it's quite a deal. 

I'm really glad to see that JapaCurry is still around and doing well.  Even though they still opened a brick and mortar at Izakaya Roku, I'm glad they decided to still keep their trucks operating.  I really hope they do come back to visit the peninsula.  Otherwise, it does make visiting them in the city a worthwhile visit and builds up anticipation for me for the next time I get to enjoy their curry.
author: Rodney H.

description:
WOHOO, Japanese food in a truck form. Japa Curry Truck had plenty of Japanese options located right in the core of the city. I'm not sure how common Japanese food is in the city, but there was a pretty long lineup in front of Japa Curry Truck. It's not cheap compared to what we normally get in Toronto, especially considering that it is a food truck, but I decided it was worth a try.

We ordered the pork cutlet with vegetables and curry, which came to a total of $10. The curry and rice weren't especially warm. However, I DID really appreciate that they put the curry in a separate container out of the pork cutlet and rice so that the rice and cutlet would not be soggy when it was consumed. The pork cutlet was extremely crisp, though I didn't think it was particularly juicy. The rice was alright and the curry was average as well, I really appreciate it if it was a little hotter, though I understand that a truck can't produce so much heat. 

I think for the price I paid for the food, a cheaper price would be better to accommodate for the food.
author: Kristy N.

description:
For all things Japanese curry, Japacurry is your truck!

Now, I love the katsu curry here. Both the chicken and pork katsu are amazingly good drowned in the sweet and spicy curry over rice. They use a lot of onion in their curry, but it is all melted such that it blends in with the smoothness of the curry. All that's left of the onion is its sweetness in the sauce. The spicy curry is not too spicy so if you're debating whether to get mild or spicy, just go with the spicy as it's fairly mild. The katsu has a nice crisp to it and the meat is moist. On the side, you get some pickled vegetables in a tiny plastic cup. All this comes together for a wonderful curry experience.

With that said, if you want some pork belly instead of katsu, spend that extra dollar! The prices for this truck are very reasonable. The pork belly is so delicious. It's fatty and soft and everything nice you'd want from pork belly. Fill yo belly with that pork belly and you'll be belly belly happy.
author: Joshua M.

description:
CASH ONLY and limit to 4 orders/person

I've gotten lunch from this truck multiple times and everything I've tried so far are tasty. 

- Pork katsu curry
- Vegetable croquette curry
- Pumpkin croquette
- Daily special bento

There's always a line, but it moves quickly. Don't come here if you're in a rush though. Many items also sell out by 12:30pm, so get here early if you want more selection.
author: Diana C.

description:
Stick with chicken katsu which i would give 4 stars.

Everything in Bento box is lacking flavor and freshness.
Scallop curry made me feel queasy afterwards. It also doesnt really look like the picture on the truck.
author: Carol K.

description:
Japa curry is love. Japa curry is life.

Seriously, there is a reason why there's always a huge line in front of this food truck - it does Japanese curry like no other place. I've had curry katsu in Waterloo, but it's nothing close to the quality here, at the same price. The crispiness of the katsu is sublime, and the curry is unmatched. But the chicken Katsu is overshadowed by the true champion of Japa Curry, the Chicken Karaage. The pieces of Karaage chicken are crispier, and juicier. When you pour the curry over it, angels sing from the heavens.

For $9, the prices are s bit high. The insane demand was bound to drive up the prices. But make no mistake - Japa curry is the best use of $9 during your lunch break. Just make sure to get in line before 11:30, so you can the longest food truck line in all of downtown SF.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Every Thursday JapaCurry is on the corner of New Montgomery & Mission from about 11am-1:30pm and it never disappoints. Admittedly, I order the same thing every time: Chicken Katsu curry (medium spice) and it is heaven! The rice is steamed perfectly and the chicken is crispy and delicious. Super filling and not a bad price - about $9 for a whole trough of lunch! The line isn't that bad if you go early or around 1pm, either way, they are super friendly and fast. 

I highly recommend if you're looking for a quick, filling, affordable lunch - go check them out! You can follow their Twitter page to see where they are, what time, and what the Daily Bento options are, which I'm also very eager to try!
author: Frankie I.

description: Pretty good curry for a good price. I get the pork katsu curry extra spicy, which really isn't that spicy at all. Since this is a good truck, they switch locations throughout the week, so you'll need to look up the location for that day.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I've been here a few times and I have no complaints so far.

I've previously ordered the chicken katsu with vegetables, the spicy sauce and jasmine rice. The quality of the chicken katsu is almost like no other place I've been to, it's simply incredible. Everywhere else it's either too dry or too juicy, and sometimes it feels like there is no meat when eating katsu in general. At JapaCurry it's always tender juicy and I feel like I'm actually eating chicken katsu done right. The chicken katsu is nice and thick and definitely makes me happy.

Now the sauce ... the infamous sauce I think they have on most their dishes. You can order in different levels of spiciness, but I like to go spicy (but the extreme spice level). The sauce is just a perfect balance of savoury, sweet and spicy. They give you a good amount of sauce so every bite you can have it's amazing flavor in every bite. 

The vegetables are boiled, and they're usually add some diversity to your meal with broccoli, cauliflower and carrots. Sometimes the vegetables aren't cooked all the way through so you get a bite of raw vegetables which is so bad because everything is really soft and melts in your mouth but when you hit this raw veggie it's such a turn off.

The line is probably a 10-20 minute wait depending what time you line up at. But it's definitely worth the wait, and you could even skip the wait if you go before noon. The service is excellent and once you do order it comes pretty fast. They were extremely apologetic and kept me up to date one time when my meal was taking a while to be made, but it's alright because they took my time into consideration and made me feel like an important customer.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Way to live up to the hype.

First time trying chicken katsu anywhere, and have to say I was impressed! The meat was crispy yet tender, and the curry was BLESS. For those of you that don't know what that means, you don't have to - just go and frickin' try it and you'll agree its BLESS too.

The only letdown were the vegetables - they definitely tasted frozen and warmed up, but they were a good way to get some extra fiber and non-carb/protein nutrition in my meal. For a total of $10, it wasn't that bad.

I usually say "no ragrets" but unfortunately I was a disappointment to my brown brethren everywhere. I ordered the curry at a "medium" level of spiciness. While still delicious, the "medium" was possibly as mild as mild gets. I was told by coworkers that you can ask for spiciness on a scale of 1-10, and medium amounts to about a 2 or 3. Definitely upping it next time around!
author: Sameer C.

description:
Since the JapaCurry truck parks near my office every Thursday, every Thursday is known as JapaCurry day. I go here almost every week and get either the katsu curry or karaage curry. I used to just dump the pickles on the rice and pour the curry over the rice and meat, but apparently this was the wrong way to eat it. If you separate the meat (like putting it onto the box's lid) and pour the curry over just the rice, then the meat stays crispy as you eat.

I've also tried their bento and cold ramen. They were decent as well but the curry is my favorite.
author: Robert P.

description: Katsu curry is fast, simple, and delicious - nothing remarkable for this simple dish but it's just right as a $9 lunch. 3.5 rounded up to support local business.
author: Brski B.

description:
Tip! If you're in a rush, get the bento box. They're cold, but you don't have to wait in line to order one. 

After having real Japanese curry in Tokyo from CoCo ICHIBANYA (the Japanese curry authority!) I now have a way to benchmark JapaCurry. I'd have to say that JapaCurry wasn't bad, and is perhaps an Americanized version of Japanese curry. There's way more meat in the meat:rice ratio here; hence, the chicken cutlet I had over my rice was gigantic in comparison to the cutlet I received in Tokyo. Furthermore, the chicken was much more greasy, and might have even had some dark meat. While it wasn't as good, it was not too far off! Definitely the best option I've yet had in San Francisco.
author: John B.

description: This truck has the best Japanese curry rice in SF. Get the kara age  curry. I typically like it much spicier. I would go more often if they accepted credit card. It would be a 5* place if they added salad/brocolli as a side to the curry dishes.
author: Saideep S.

description:
No line at 1pm on a Wednesday at 1st and Howard. Chicken Katsu Curry was perfection. Better than Muracci's. Only $9 too.

For next time: The Vegetarian Bento and Pumpkin croquette look pretty good.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Great tasting, authentic Japanese cuisine from a food truck? Yes, most definitely.  I had the spicy Chicken Karaage. It was hot without being overwhelming, and I enjoyed the great flavor.

The price was about what you expect for lunch in the financial district, but the portions were good. So, it was worth it.
author: Trevor R.

description: Very tasty curry. You cannot go wrong with anything on their menu! Their katsu curry is my favorite.
author: Grace A.

description:
Yummm! I've been seeing this food truck around work and finally got to tried it on a Friday. We came around 12ish and it was VERY busy. The wait was kinda long so be prepared! 

You can order on their website but there's a wait for that pick up. I looked around 12 and it quoted me thirty mins. Depending on the food you get it's probably best to wait in person to get it. You can skip the line if you are getting bento boxes since it's already prepared. My friends got the teriyaki chicken and it looked okay. It was served room temperature so if you were craving something warm I wouldn't recommend it. 

I got the pork katsu with curry and rice. You can have your curry normal or spicy. I asked for spicy not knowing how spicy it will be and I can tolerate Asian style numbing spicy, but this curry slowly creeps up on you and by the end of the mea your mouth is on fire. So beware! Curry has bits of veggies and it doesn't taste like the curry cubes you get at the market. This was insanely flavorful and the katsu was fried to perfection. 

I will need to come earlier and the price were all around $9-10ish. Not bad for a great lunch in Fidi!
author: Sarah I.

description: I had never experienced Japanese curry before coming here, but now I'm obsessed. JapaCurry has managed to perfect their food to the point that they've developed a very loyal customer basis. My friends and I would regularly get lunch here once a week, if not more. I always got the chicken katsu curry. The chicken is very tasty and tender, and the curry equally amazing with a distinct homemade flavor. I was amazed that the amount of curry they provide yields the perfect rice-to-curry ratio - not too soggy and not too dry. I've found that this is extremely rare to find in most restaurants' curry dishes. I never thought I'd be able to eat the exact same thing every week for months and not get bored, but I still find myself craving their chicken katsu curry because it's simply so well prepared. As a result of their popularity, the lines are quite long, so be sure to come early!
author: Zareen C.

description: On Thursdays this truck is near Mission and 2nd which is perfect for lunch. I've gotten the tofu bento and tofu katsu- both delicious. Order ahead... sometimes the line gets really long.
author: Lindsay L.

description: Great food and price! But the line gets really long, so order your lunch ahead through eat24!
author: Jong-Kai Y.

description: This review is for the chicken teriyaki we ordered for lunch yesterday. First, it was cold, like fridge cold food. It was salty, the veggies were dry. I am not sure if the intention was we should have heated it up. I didn't want to give a one star because this is my first time. But really so disappointed.
author: Nnt G.

description: Delicious, and you can't beat the price! The chicken katsu is perfect, reminds me of a little restaurant I go to back home.
author: Jordan F.

description:
My time in SF was nearing an end and I hadn't had the opportunity to score to quality time with my volcano goddess. Taking the opportunity to hit the streets (and mail a bill; yes, she mocked me for doing so), we were on the hunt for lunch eats when we happened upon the JapaCurry Truck right as it was opening. Being that neither one of us live in SF, our excitement for what the truck had to offer was briefly tempered by checking the Yelp reviews. The 4-star average let us give in to our food desires and we were customers 3 & 4. 

I haven't lived in a city with a robust Asian culinary scene in four years. Nashville is making strides but it's nowhere near the depth of what you can find on the west coast (duh). Not having had non-sushi Japanese food in far too long, I jumped at the chance to bring some Japanese curry into my life. After all, it's in the title. It has to be good, no? Yes. I knew curry was on the menu but wasn't sure about the protein until I saw the kara-age. Fried chicken is ALWAYS the right choice to the Kentucky native and Nashville local. For those who might not know, Japanese curry is not as flavor-forward (aggressive?) as Indian curry. In fact, to my tastes, it's a bit sweeter. So, expectations. My plate of chicken and rice was a lot bigger than I anticipated. Once I doused the ingredients with the curry, I dug in. Oh man. The fried chicken was meaty, flavorful on its own and sopped up the curry-stew like a sponge. In fact, it was so good at blending the flavors and mediums, I couldn't finish my lunch. Me. A charter member of the clean plate club. Leaving food on the table. I struggled to finish the last bites but my volcano goddess admonished me about my growing food baby belly and reminded me that I should only be eating a fistful of food at a time. Yeah, we don't eat together very often. Admitting defeat, I left the last forkfuls of rice and bites of chicken in the container and wondered where I could find a similar dish in the 615. I totally get with the JapaCurry truck is a hit with SF and I'm pleased that it was my last purchased meal during this trip to the City By The Bay. Way to let me go out on top, JapaCurry. I'll be dining from you again.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I attended the Soy and Tofu Festival, and found the opportunity to give the JapaCurry food truck a try.  Why?  Because, I'm tired of bread and wanted to try what the latest craze around town was about.  The Original Ramen Burger! 

This review will be short and sweet, as I only tried the Ramen Burger ($8).  Here's what it consists of:  
~ a 100% ground beef patty
~ sitting on baby arugula
~ topped with scallions and shoyu glaze
~ between a hand-made ramen bun 
  
An interesting little burger that was combined really well.  The beef was juicy, but I think the shoyu glaze was what enhanced the overall flavor.  The noodles started to break after eating half of it.  Maybe I just squeezed too hard, IDK.  But I did enjoyed it as it wasn't too greasy.  For now, a tough 3 to 4 star decision, but with the price versus size, I had to sway it to the left.     

Unfortunately, the Tofu Burger ($9) was SOLD OUT!  Basically tofu between a ramen bun.  They offered other items on the menu like Japanese curry of course, and bento boxes, but I passed on those for now since it was a tofu festival.  For now a solid 3, as I shall save my hunger for ramen burgers and curry some other day!
author: Ron R.

description:
Everyone needs to try Japacurry. It's good, and definitely on par w the Marakaru (something like that) famous pick up Japanese curry spot on Kearny that people line up 30 mins for lunch for.

But, it's no where near as good as the flavor of curry in Japan. Ok, I'm spoiled by 2 weeks of traveling there, but it'll suffice for the USA. Plus, only $9 for good size, with nice katsu chicken, pork and other meats too and radish on top. Definitely good. Go before 12 and look at their Facebook and Twitter as they move around downtown soma.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Definitely not my favorite or the best Japanese curry I have had. Muraccis and volcano curry are definitely better as well as the ones I have had in Japan prior. 

Chicken katsu curry: 3/5: chicken was perfectly fried, it was crispy and the chicken was juicy and moist. I added veggies for $1, and I got a good amount of cauliflower and broccoli, strangest part was that they gave French fries as well. Now the disappointing part that matters the most is the curry. It has a great consistency but I ordered it spicy and well let's just say it lacked any spice. It had a very mild curry flavor that could not compare to muraccis or even volcano. If it was spicier and had better flavor then I would be satisfied. 

Overall, it was ok curry, but it's not my favorite nor is it one that I would make another trip to try again. The only thing that I do want to try is their curry sandwich that looks intriguing. 

Total for one: $10
author: Stella J.

description:
Either my tastes have changed, or they've gotten better since I wrote my initial review, but after having eaten at a number of curry shops across the city now, I'd actually say that JapaCurry is probably my second fav-- wait, no, now that Kare-ken (my favorite) closed down, I suppose that makes them the best I've found in SF.

Get the katsu curry (either of them), and if you like spicy, make sure you either 5x or 10x spicy that order! Waits can be pretty horrendous during lunch, so, pro tip: order on Order Ahead, and either have them deliver, or go pick up. Why wait in line for 20-30 minutes when you can wait in your office?
author: Johnny W.

description:
This truck always has long lines, and only takes cash.
But it still gets the business because it's all worth it. 
It's a food truck, people. I'm not saying it's authentic japanese or fine cuisine level. But if you want some warm, delicious, homey curry food, you can't find anything better! $9-14 ish for a curry dish, or you can opt to take the bento box which is served cold but you can skip the line. Not expensive, and actually filling. The ladies who work here are also nice af, and if you want you can order ahead online to pick it up without having to wait in the line!

Best dish hands down: chicken katsu curry. She gives you a spice level option too.. if you can handle spicy, 5S is the way to go.
author: Grace P.

description:
Got curry at the JapaCurry truck today on 1st and Howard. There was barely any wait (I got there at around 1pm). I asked for Katsu Pork Curry, gave them some money, and in exchange they gave me a small cylindrical container and a compostable takeout box with presumably some food inside

The pork katsu was by far the best pork katsu curry I've had in my life. As I bit into it, a gathering of angels took me 50 feet in the air and showed me to my cloud palace with fountains of curry sauce and sizzling pork katsu. And every bite was like that. Just again and again. 

The pork katsu was perfectly crisp on the outside, and juicy and tender on the inside. Nothing was soggy or too dry. The pieces were sliced perfectly and the quality of meat was exactly what I looked for in katsu.

Curry sauce was mediocre.
author: Victor H.

description:
The people who work here are incredibly nice. I stopped by for the first time and they happened to be closing up, so they gave me a tofu bento for free. Despite being cold, it was still delicious. It came with tofu, a croquette, salad with eggplant and kabocha, and tsukemono. 
Their truck is outside the Academy of Art building on New Montgomery and Mission every Thursday. Coming from Hawaii, this is exactly the lunch option I needed near work, so I'll definitely be back.
author: Steels M.

description:
My co-workers and I make this our typical Thursday lunch as the truck is parked on Mission and New Montgomery Streets in the city. I have always been a fan of katsu (Hawaiian BBQ style), however never had the curry until my boss insisted I give it a try. Once I gave in and gave it a try I have been hooked ever since.  

I used to be terrified to add any extra scoops of the spicy chili powder to the curry sauce but I have slowly climbed the ladder and now they won't allow me to add anymore after the 10 times spicy that a couple of us add each time we visit the truck. 

You get a healthy portion of food for the price and most times it will get me through lunch and I will have about half left over for dinner. The lines can be long if you get there anytime before 1 pm, so be prepared to wait a good 15 minutes for your number to be called. A great value and I suggest you give it a try if you are looking for something to get your taste buds jumping!  

The only curry in the bay hotter than this is Steph on the court! Go Dubs! And I will see you Thursday gang!
author: Josh H.

description:
After going back a few times, I'm bumping up my rating to 4 stars. I've learned that ordering the Chicken Katsu pretty much always guarantees a much larger portion when compared with the Pork Katsu, so that's now my go-to.

Regarding the consistency of the curry sauce, I think this is something I'll just have to get used to. Muracci's (also in FiDi) has a very similar style of sauce, and while very nice, is around $2 more expensive. Worth checking out both places regardless. I'm still hoping to eventually find somewhere that has a thicker sauce, but until that day I'll continue to go to JapaCurry.
author: Joe B.

description:
Awesome chicken karaage - perfectly fried chicken  thighs with rice n Cole slaw.
Even the chicken katsu is pretty good.
Always a good food truck for our team when we are looking for delicious food on Fridays.
author: Div M.

description:
Another one of the few spots that didn't have a crazy wait at the JPop festival. It still took my friend about 30 minutes to get his Okonomiyaki and Chicken & Pork Katsu Curries. 

* Okonomiyaki - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/japacurry-truck-san-francisco?select=DhlhFlQzuTIDNQ_J2vfxZQ#DhlhFlQzuTIDNQ_J2vfxZQ
While the toppings and flavors were good, we realized that this was mostly made up of cabbage! The filling was probably about 70% cabbage, 25% dough, and a couple pieces of shrimp. It really should have been more dough and a lot more seafood!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Time is Wednesday night 00:23am now. 

Can't fall asleep, too excited because tomorrow is JAPACURRY THURSDAY!!!!!
author: Xi L.

description:
After experiencing all of the awesome stuff there was to do at the JPOP festival, my pals and I were starving and needed some grub.  Luckily, there was at least a dozen food trucks at the event which all varieties of delicious asian foods.  However, the delicious and familiar aromas coming from the JapaCurry truck drew me near and I absolutely had to have an old favorite that they served.

I ordered their okonomiyaki, which was actually quite good!  Despite not being made fresh to order (I think they reheat them in a tunnel oven) they retain the great texture, smell, flavor, and spirit of great Japanese omelets.  They're a great value at $7 and I was very satisfied at the end and it was big enough to share.  I'd definitely get it again.

Service was fast, but a tad disorganized.  Customers received tickets, but since the number wasn't being called out, there was some confusion.  Besides that, prices seemed pretty fair for a food truck and weren't monsterously overpriced.  I definitely want to try their curry on the next visit!

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Delicious Chicken Katsu curry. The chicken has the right amount of crispiness and the curry is tasteful as well. Unfortunately it's only close by my workplace on Thursday. Otherwise I don't mind lunching there everyday. Would be nice if they could come during dinner too hahaha
author: Gott P.

description:
Ten bucks for this much food! Are you kidding me. This is awesome. And I'm not just talking about the amount. The chicken's moist, tender and yet super crispy on the outside. 

I had the karaage curry and the only thing I'm sorry about is that I don't have a bigger stomach to get the ramen burger (I'm a fiend for ramen burgers) and the curry sandwich also. Life's so unfair.

Now, to wait for next Thursday, till they come by my office once again.
author: Avadhut P.

description:
One of my favorite food trucks!  I've had their Kurobuta Sausage Curry, Pork Katsu Curry, and most recently their Chicken Teriyaki Bento.  For the curries, I usually get spicy which has a nice kick to it.  They put the curry on the side so it doesn't get the rice soggy, which is nice.  The Kurobuta Sausage with curry seems a little odd, but I just eat the sausage separately from the curry and rice.  The tonkatsu has a nice crunchy batter and it comes out freshly fried so it's tasty.  Portions are good so it's a definitely a fulfilling meal.

The Chicken Teriyaki was okay.  The sauce was a bit sweet for me, but I did enjoy the authentic Japanese side dishes that came with it, such as hijiki, kiriboshi daikon, kinpira gobo, spaghetti salad, and tsukemono.  I look forward to trying their other bentos next time.
author: Erica S.

description:
I know waaaaaay too many people that treat Japacurry as the holy grail of chicken katsu. At this point no one at work talks to me anymore because I said the katsu was "A-OK." :(

It's definitely not bad chicken katsu. The curry isn't really all that good, and I honestly would not be able to tell it apart from other katsu in a taste test. It's good, but not memorable, and it's kind of plain, and honestly I don't think it's worth the long line you have to endure during lunch.
author: Max Z.

description:
I come by this place every Thursday at 11:30 to beat the rush. My advice is not to come at 11:30, because then I will start having to come at 11:00. The reason for the long lines? This place is worth standing on Mission for a good 10 minutes just to grab some of their curry. How good is it? Rice, spice, and everything nice. Bring your friends, watch all of the techies feel uncomfortable in the direct sunlight, enjoy the food. 

I'lll see you there.
author: Jake B.

description: I love JapaCurry! They come to Fidi district a lot and so far I have tried their Pork Curry and the Fried Chicken Curry and both are amazing! The portion is big and the price is fair. You can also modify the spiciness of the curry sauce upon order.
author: Athena C.

description: The pork cutlet was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. The actual curry was thick and flavourful, not too sweet or too salty. The side of pickled vegetables was very delicious and also had a good balance of saltiness and sourness.
author: James S.

description:
This review is for their ramen burger.

The typical burger bun has been replaced with ramen. The burger was alright. It was a bit on the dry end, but the sauce they used really helped! The burger also included arugula and goat cheese. It definitely worked well together. I'm just upset that this didn't blow me away. If they put a regular bun instead of the ramen, I think it would've tasted just the same. It was small, too. For almost $9, I'd rather spend it elsewhere. 

At least I got ramen burger off my check list. I think next time I'll stick to their infamous curry dishes instead.
author: Fiona L.

description:
Every Thursday, the elevators in my building smell faintly of JapaCurry, and that's not a complaint. 

I enjoy the katsu, karrage, and pork belly curries. The meat is tender. It's a good idea to add veggies for $1 so you're not just eating meat and rice.
author: Theresa M.

description:
A solid pick for lunch in the fidi!

I've been sort of partial to Muracci's or Volcano, but JapaCurry was a pleasant surprise.

There are thin slivers of onion that are melty oniony goodness in the curry that is nice and spicy.  My only "complaint" is that I'm really used to potatoes and carrots in my curry, and you won't find those in JapaCurry's. Also, the pork katsu was perfectly crisp, but it could do with a little extra seasoning - ie salt and pepper.

Worth trying out for lunch! Long lines move quickly too.
author: Susan Y.

description: I had their pork katsu before and was lucky enough to get the pork belly curry. The portions were a little small both times, and their pork belly was too fatty in my opinion. But their spicy curry was top notch; spicy enough to make me sweat but still enjoy it all the way. Beware of their line though, around 11:30 it gets crazy. I'd recommend going at 11:00 or after the rush around 1PM. Also CASH ONLY!
author: Bowen Y.

description: Japa is one of my go-to food trucks in the City. While the bento box is good, go with the katsu curry. I can't stay away. I get food envy every time I see someone at lunch with it. Comes with pork or chicken (both excellent). You'll get the fried meat served over rice and a container of curry sauce (either regular or spicy) to pour over as you like. It's simple and delicious.
author: Cameron S.

description:
I can always count on JapaCurry to bring me my weekly happiness, Thursdays on the corner of New Montgomery right by my office! 

If you're willing to brave the insanely long lines, I guarantee you will enjoy JapaCurry's impressive selection of curries, katsus, and bento boxes. Try the katsu curry with a pumpkin croquette- they're earth-shattering. 

If I could reduce the price by a dollar or two and cut the ridiculous lines, I'd give this place 6/5 stars!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Sorry, but Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill's curry has got you beat.  No contest.  

Service = fast
Chicken karaage = delicious.
Curry = lackluster 

Bring cash.
author: Fannie S.

description:
So yummy!
I used to think Japanese-style curry was a little boring, but this truck made me realize how yummy it could actually get. 
I had the pork belly, which was on special that day. The meat was pretty good quality, and I was impressed with the amount you get for the price.
author: Justin A.

description: I pretty much go here ever week for lunch. I've tried chicken katsu & curry dishes all throughout the city and JapaCurry is definitely my favorite. Their curry is vegetarian and it's amazing: lots of strong flavors and very onion-y. The katsu is super crisy and the chicken is very tender and not dry at all, maybe because they use dark meat. Also you can get it as spicy as you want: 1S, 2S, 3S, ..., etc. My vegetarian colleagues also really like the vegetable curry with the pumpkin croquette.
author: Andrew D.

description: I had the Japanese katsu chicken curry. It was definitely good and well done, however nothing extra ordinary IMHO. It is great place to get a lunch in San Francisco and I will visit this place again to try more food here.
author: Piyush K.

description: I visited the Japacurry truck today with a friend, and ordered the spicy chicken katsu curry. I've had katsu curry from other spots in the Financial District, but Japacurry has their recipe down! The chicken is tender and juicy, and they give you just enough to keep you full for the rest of the day. The line may be a little long, but they crank orders out quickly. Any meal under $10 in the Financial District is a good price, and at $9, Japacurry is well worth the money. I'm definitely trying the kurobota pork belly next time.
author: Monica M.

description:
Japanese curry is not really readily available everywhere, so a Japanese Curry truck peeked my interest. especially after being to Japan and have some of the best Curry there, i wanted to find something over here that is comparable. And volia JapaCurry Truck. While not as good as the Curry in Japan, this small colorful foodtruck has championed the curry sauce and the prefection on their cooks of the meat. the chicken is moist and juicy, with the crispy outside.  and the sausage tastes awesome. I got the spicy curry, and it wasn't as hot as i would have liked, but it had a good kick to it. I would definitely go back to this truck when i have a craving for some good curry. 

Tip: order using OrderAhead and you don't have to stand in line. although you do have to wait at the truck for a little bit, as they like to serve it to you hot.
author: Anuj C.

description:
I stumbled into the JapaCurry food truck after I tumbled into the J-Pop festival. It was love at first bite.

My little boy allowed me a taste of his Kara-age (boneless Japanese fried chicken) while I tucked into the curry chicken katsu which was delicious - although I wished for more heat and I ordered it "medium."

And as we enjoyed our lunch, particularly the fried chicken, I smugly thought, "This is terrific, I can make this!"

Wrong.

To insure my success, I bought the pricey air-chilled chicken (at Whole Foods no less). Yes, I purchased the potato starch to roll the chicken in at Nijiya market on Post Street (love that grocery). Yep, I'm a decent cook and I did remember the slices of fresh lemon to squeeze on the fried chicken.

All this attention to detail and JapaCurry buried me: Kara-age is a deceptively simple dish and try as you may, it'll be a pale comparison to what you can buy hot off the JapaCurry truck.

Deliciously cooked to juicy perfection, it's sensibly priced too. Quite frankly, I'm a little envious I couldn't compete.

JapaCurry- your seemingly uncomplicated awesomeness is quite amazing. You win! 

Wait, I still win: I can dine right off your truck- yum.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I don't think I'm in love with food trucks as much as others are, so hopefully my review isn't inflated by any food truck bias thoughts. I like em, but I like sitting down at a restaurant as well. And just FYI to put it out there, the best food trucks are taco trucks in Oakland. Those are the OG food trucks before things like off the grid became famous ha.

Anyways back to what you came here to read... The japacurry truck! 
What a beautiful orange truck. I spotted it down the block and was excited to see that the line wasn't too long. Opens at 11:30-2 on Howard and 1st in SF today, and there was maybe 8 people waiting for their orders and zero people in the order line at 11:45am when I got there. 

I ordered the katsu for 8 bucks because it seemed like the go to popular item. And when trying new places I like to try the popular item to know what people are talking about! I like to be in the hoop, yadadamean? (In real English that means: "understand what I am speaking of?").

The katsu was good! The curry was pretty decent, not awesome curry but for 8 bucks... Katsu curry and rice is good enough, especially in an area where food can be $10+ if it's not a fast food chain. 
Overall, I've had better food, both katsu and curry, but I do acknowledge the price and speediness in my order (3 minutes to get my food). 

Will be back! But not in love by any means.

Failed to add that they take CASH ONLY! 
They should have that on their website that's more obvious cause I didn't know when I got there (luckily I had 10), and neither did the two hungry ladies in front of me that got turned away for not having cash.
author: Ben T.

description:
JapaCurry Truck offers some quick, affordable Japanese comfort food for lunch if you're in the FiDi area. I love the sweet yet spicy taste of the curry, especially with the choice of customizing levels of spiciness. I enjoyed the CHICKEN KARAAGE for its tender and juicy pieces of chicken meat, and crispy skin and breading. The PORK KATSU was also tasty, but I found it to be slightly dry. I appreciated the big container of curry to mix with the rice provided. 

Overall, I'd come back again for lunch when the craving hits.

Helpful Hint: 
- If you're looking for them at New Montgomery/Mission St. on Thursdays, go a little further to Mission and 2nd. The constant construction in the area makes it hard for them to park at that corner.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Forget your neti pot, just try some spicy curry from this truck to clear up your sinuses!

I was in an indecisive mood at midday when curry crossed my mind and my colleague suggested we head for the Japacurry truck. The katsu curry was spicy and faultless (except for its omission of potatoes). I was also pleased to find they offered brown rice for a small surcharge.

Beyond curry, JapaCurry does bento boxes (chicken teriyaki, BBQ beef, soba). I'll probably be unable to resist the katsu on my next visit but it's nice to know in case you're coming here with someone less excited about curry.
author: Miriam W.

description: Yummmmmmmmmmmm. Katsu curry medium hot. Good serving size, good flavors, good price. One of my few go to places for lunch during a work day.
author: Annie S.

description:
Are you kidding me?! A half an hour line for a stinking cutlet with rice with some mediocre curry drizzled over it? And they charge 10$? The food is absolutely mediocre, I don't know whether the people who eat here have terribly low standards for food or whether it's because they're 'riding the latest trends in food'.

I'm sick of uninspired fusion cuisines that's characteristic of SF, this is one of them. I would not go back, there are many, MANY places in SF that are much better tasting, larger portions, and cheaper. Don't sell yourself short on this excuse of a food truck selling uninspired Japanese Indian food.
author: Davis W.

description:
"Open, Open, Open..." *eye raping the bright orange truck*

As I waited for the JapaCurry Truck to open, I felt like the annoying woman who plasters her face against the window in the Mervyns' commercial...

There's nothing more comforting than a plate of Katsu Curry; slightly sticky rice infused with fragrant savory spices accompanied by a crispy, juicy slab of meat. I have yet to find a solid Katsu Curry (I haven't tried Muracchi's yet) so when I heard about the arrival of the JapaCurry Truck last year, I was ecstatic.  After an excruciating five-month wait, I finally got to try JapaCurry's Katsu Curry when they were at Off The Grid - Civic Center on Friday, April 8, 2011.

OTG - Civic Center starts at 11:30 AM, however, my collogues and I arrived 10 minutes prior to beat the lines. I stood in line at 11:25 AM (2 people in front of me) and as I waited for the JapaCurry Truck to "Open, Open, Open", I could smell the aroma of katsu frying permeating into the air. AHHHHHH... I ordered the Katsu Curry with Pork ($8) and within 2 minutes of ordering, it was ready. 

After a much-anticipated wait and hearing all the rave reviews, I think my high expectations of JapaCurry caused a slight disappointment. Or, it may be due to the fact that I previously devoured a mouth-watering Pork Belly Bun from Chairman Bao which curbed my appetite. 

A warm golden brown pork cutlet topped a heaping portion of sticky Japanese short grain rice with fukujinzuke pickles sprinkled on the side. The curry sauce was served in separate container so the pork katsu and rice wouldn't get soggy. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thAbNIGH1pWMi6uPw39e1w?select=rq56wbsQQu5CnB7tvPipnQ

The thick cut of pork katsu was coated with just the right amount of batter to produce that crunchy exterior while still being able to taste all the tender and juicy porkyness of the katsu. Once you slather the curry sauce on top of the katsu, it gets soggy quick so use the curry as a "dipping" sauce instead if you like your katsu to remain crisp. Although the curry sauce had the perfect consistency to coat the back of a spoon without dripping all over the place, I was expecting a bigger punch in flavor. I felt like it was missing the pungent and complex flavor of spices (i.e. coriander, cumin, cinnamon, cayenne, and ginger). It was definitely missing heat though as the "spicy" was more like a black pepper taste to me. The fukujinzuke pickles added a touch of acidity to help balance the richness, although I wish there was an option to add more as teaspoon is just not enough for me. 

JapaCurry is definitely one of the better food trucks out there in terms of authenticity, quality and pricing for the amount of food given. I think the deliciousness of the Pork Belly Bun from Chairman Bao skewed my rating a bit, so I foresee a remake part duex of the Mervyns' commercial coming soon to an OTG near you...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: JapanCurry is so good. I missed not being able to get cause I work 7:30-to 3:30 on weekday nowadays. Recently, I went to murrachi's curry and it wasn't nearly as good. I also love the daily special bento from JapanCurry
author: Hui Y.

description: One of my favorite places to get Pork Katsu Curry or Karaage. The line is long, but it goes by quick enough if you have some friends to talk to. For an extra $1 you can add vegetables, and that really fills me up. I'm not a big fan of super spicy, but I find their curries enjoyable, and you can specify how spicy you want it from 1 to 10. (I got for the 2 and love it). Its cash only, they used to take LevelUp, but not anymore. Still, its one of my favorite food trucks in SF.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Had a chance to try their food at the Soy abd Tofu Festival in Japantown.
Their prices were discounted for the festival (?) or the lateness of the day (3pm)

We shared:

Pumpkin croquette
Veggie croquette

Chicken kara-age with curry rice.  I was in the mood for Japanese curry so it really hit the spot---or many spots on my untrim body.

Enjoyed our meals. More of a large snack sized portion than a full meal--
but we were feeling pretty ravenous.

Staff was very sweet.

Will definitely try them again.

As with most food trucks you can track them down through their website.
author: Rinky N.

description:
I miss regularly going to Muracci's on Kearny when I worked in that part of the FiDi because Japanese comfort food is well... comforting. When my mom was alive, I was thrilled when she made chicken curry rice for dinner. Only Muracci's brought back some of those memories with their most excellent food, but like a beloved neighbor that suddenly moves away from the fishing village in an Ozu film, I was feeling Muracci's was becoming more of a distant memory that has gained distance in the intervening months.

That was before JapaCurry came on the scene and in an orange truck no less. I only became aware of them when the controversy heated up in the blogosphere over its Second Street location from the protests raised by Alison Rowe of Harvest & Rowe, who complained loudly that JapaCurry would interfere with her bricks-and-mortar business. Interesting theory. She should perhaps explore the mediocrity of her food and the high prices of her own operation before throwing stones at passing food trucks.

Much to Ms. Rowe's chagrin, the publicity is obviously helping business at JapaCurry since I was barely able to get a meal scraped together by the time I arrived around 1:30PM at their Mission/New Montgomery location. I was told all I could score was sauce and rice for about $3. Hey, I'm Japanese. I'll take it. As it turned out, I was able to get some of the remaining Vegetable Curry (normally $7) and got extra sauce to go (see photo).

I really liked the sauce. Spicy but not edgy. Now more than ever, I'm more motivated than ever to get there early to try the $8 Katsu Curry or the $7.50 Kurobuta Pork Sausage Curry. Maybe I'll just take my curry bento box to a table at Harvest & Rowe, so I can recreate Jack Nicholson's "chicken between your knees" diner scene in "Five Easy Pieces". http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6wtfNE4z6a8

In case you're interested...
My review of Harvest & Rowe (8/01/2010): http://www.yelp.com/biz/harvest-and-rowe-san-francisco#hrid:ce9PuytGI57ned_wy_PaaA
My review of Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill (5/08/2008): http://www.yelp.com/biz/muraccis-japanese-curry-and-grill-san-francisco#hrid:S5wsf3TD3aMo2SB5XAzcvQ

FOOD - 4 stars...spicy curry reminds me of Muracci and mom, in that order
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...uhh, it's a truck
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...hey, they were willing to sell me sauce for $3, and I took it...that's service
TOTAL - 4 stars...a nice idea for a food truck that satisfies my soul...guess I can skip that $10 Harvest & Rowe salad now
author: Ed U.

description:
This newest player in the mobile food scene is causing quite a stir, and not just for the food.  I'll get to the food after the jump.

Apparently, the hullabaloo is not limited to eager patrons in line for delicious Japanese curry and bento boxes coming out of a massive orange truck.  Even finding a decent parking spot came with controversy for this rookie, as some other business owner screamed "N-I-M-B-Y" and tried to prevent Mr. Hamada's truck from parking nearby:  

 http://blogs.sfweekly.com/foodie/2011/01/japacurry_harvest_and_rowe_oust_food_truck.php

Ugh, I tell ya, this brings back haunting memories of Ike's eviction.  Just a thought, but maybe the concerned owner in the article should spend less time worrying about Mr. Hamada and more time improving her own three star rating.  In a foodie town like SF, people can be quite unforgiving when it comes to food.  Let's all try to get along and give this rookie a chance to shine.  After all, this orange truck certainly has a lot to offer.  Also, increasing foot traffic in the area might actually benefit these businesses, but I digress.

Enough about NIMBY neighbors and back to the food.  The pork katsu was nice, warm and crispy.  The curry - whoa, nellie - out of this world...very rich and flavorful.  Don't be bashful and just dip those pork pieces into the curry bowl, go ahead and pour the entire darn thing on your bed of rice, the curry wont overpower the meal, I promise.  Also, you have to try the spicy variety.  Even if you're not that much into spice, it adds a nice extra kick that you'll appreciate. 

Not sure I can weigh in on the comparison between Muracci's at this point as I haven't been to Muracci's for a while.

The line tends to form quickly, so I suggest you make it out close to 11:30 a.m., if possible.  For a very busy spot, service was lightning fast, very friendly too.  A 4.5 for me, possible upgrade to come.
author: Angel S.

description:
OH MY.  I have seriously been missing out on Japanese Katsu Curry since I've moved to San Francisco.

As I've mentioned in my previous review, I always assumed that I didn't like curry.  The real problem I've been suffering from is that I've not had good curry...ever.  Queue JapaCurry where I finally made the step into having chicken katsu curry from JapaCurry's truck.  My impression: OUTSTANDING!  There are very few restaurants here in SF (including fancy pants ones) that can get me to overturn my conviction of a food I don't like into something I do like.  JapaCurry has earned all 5 stars in my mind.  I literally ate the entire thing, and didn't leave any rice spared in the box.  I didn't use all the curry sauce (is eating JUST curry sauce something one does if they enjoy it?  Seems like it needs to go with something), but I enjoyed every bite of my lunch.  I enjoyed it so much, I'm actually craving it on a regular basis now.

Congratulations JapaCurry, you've converted a non-believer of curry into a craver of your food out of me!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Dear Muracci's,

Don't worry, you are still my favorite Japanese curry restaurant!  However, I now have a favorite curry food truck too.  

JapaCurry has finally made it to the FiDi.***  Its curry is as rich and flavorful as yours but of course their menu is limited to a few curries and a couple of bentos.
