For $8, I got a nice sized piece of Chicken Katsu, lots of rice, and a bit of red pickled cabbage all in a compostable container.  Delicious!  
  
Your favorite curry polygamist, 
Amy C. 
 
p.s.  Would you consider getting a "Buy 12 curries, get 1 free" card too? 
 
*** Curry drama!  http://bit.ly/g587ZG
author: Amy C.

description:
I tried this at Off the Grid @ Fort Mason. My sister ordered the chicken katsu curry box. It was advertised for $8, but once my sister approached the truck, the lady worker slashed the price to $6. Is that good, or bad...? It wasn't bad. The curry was pretty scrumptious. A large scoop of it onto the rice, with a piece of chicken... it was a bite size of deliciousness. 

I didn't eat fried foods for 2 months, until I ate this katsu. It was good, but wasn't totally worth it, but I knew I would be eating fried foods the next day for dim sum! The bad thing was that the dish wasn't hot enough, only luke warm. And with the gusty winds at Fort Mason, it quickly became cold less than halfway through our meal.  

3.5 stars
author: Leslie P.

description:
The JapaCurry truck is usually on 1st and Howard in the FiDi every week.  This past week, I ventured out there with coworkers to brave the line and try them out for the first time.  I liked how they had tons of options...Katsu, Teriyaki, Croquette, Karaage.  Most of them were $8 so I got the Croquette because they were offering their Pumpkin croquette too.  After a modest wait for the food and walking back to the office, I finally got to open up the curry and doused over the rice and croquette.  

From a flavor standpoint, this curry was very aromatic.  There's no way to not smell this when walking less than 20 feet away from an open curry container.  When eating this, it tastes a bit different than what I'm smelling.  Maybe it's because I ordered mild spiciness but I didn't get the same tasting satisfaction as compared to what I smelled.  The pumpkin flavor in the croquette plus the curry was definitely unique...I've never had that combo before even in a sit-down restaurant ever.  

I'm likely going to try JapaCurry again and go spicy with some katsu or the kara-age.  They don't have a huge following for having sub-standard food.  I'll update my rating after trying them for the second time.
author: Ben H L.

description:
BEST. CHICKEN. KATSU. EVERRR!

And I'm not saying this because I was starving. The chicken katsu was piping hot with a mouthwatering crispiness and juiciness. I've had good pork katsu, but not chicken katsu! It was SOO good!

The curry had a delicious kick that lingered in my mouth. The combination of katsu and curry together was divine! I couldn't stop eating until it was all gone.

Service: Friendly and speedy! Ordered and got my food within 5 minutes! 
Price: Reasonable! $7-$8. 
Portion: Hearty! Rice, meat and a container of curry! 
Menu: Pork katsu, kurobota sausage, chicken katsu, vegetable & potato croquette curry
Love: The fun design and the stand-up counter at the truck for eating!

I think Muracci's has a competitor in town. 

JapaCurry, welcome to the OtG family!! =D
author: Marti L.

description:
The Chicken Karaage was pretty good. 

You can never go wrong when it comes to food truck in San Francisco. 

When deciding what to get from these truck. Always get their specialty. Or whatever the recipe of the day. It's a part of food adventure. You never know what new flavor your mouth will discover 

Overall this good truck is bomb
author: irwin v.

description:
Came here to get lunch with my coworkers today! The truck isn't too far away from our office, so it was a nice walk. 

I absolutely LOVE Japanese curry.....and when my coworkers asked me if I wanted to go grab JapaCurry, my eyes lit up and I announced, "YES."

Line was pretty decent on a Tuesday afternoon. This truck is CASH ONLY. But thank god for coworkers who bring cash.....and venmo!

I ordered a spicy pork katsu curry. If you want extra curry, you can ask for it! The curry comes in spicy or non-spicy, the overall meal just comes with rice, a decent-sized katsu, and a small container of pickled radish. The curry has bits of chopped onions, but no vegetables. You can request some vegetables (carrots and some potatoes), but it's not standard. 

I thought the meal was good, but I've had better curry in SF...muracci's and Kare-ken. Still a good place for a quick lunch break. They also have small side dishes such as pickled lotus root available for purchase as well. If curry isn't your thing....they also have daily bento boxes available too! 

Swing by JapaCurry if you haven't tried it before for lunch!
author: Rachel C.

description: Ahh JapaCurry, It's a workday staple in SoMa. I usually go for the Pork Katsu Curry, but the Karaage is delicious as well. Don't skimp on the spiciness level either, I'd recommend 6 or greater. And don't forget, cash only!
author: Matt G.

description:
It was a rainy debut for the JapaCurry truck tonight. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5jPH6xAzp0j7lfLQaM7cZw/l Mr. Hamada (prefers to be called Jay) was taking the orders. I got the pork katsu curry ($7). http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hH-WRHzQSQ6RK7DURcYf8g/l Service was super fast, literally a few minutes after placing an order the food was ready for pickup in the next window. At first it seemed like if they didn't have any customers, but in reality the people were being served faster than any other food truck at OTG.

The curry sauce had shredded beef but my order had no visible veggies. Next time I'll try the veggie croquette curry to see what that's like. I got there early so I was able to order what I wanted. Overall it has decent flavor and the katsu was perfectly fried. But Muracci's remains my favorite place for Japanese curry in the city.

Get schedule updates here: http://www.japacurry.com/
Twitter is updated less frequently: http://twitter.com/JapaCurry
author: Luis C.

description:
SactoMoFo 3

My favorite truck at SactoMoFo 3! 

I loved the karrage (fried chicken). One reason is because there weren't any bones. :P There was a thin layer of fried batter that made the chicken crispy and not greasy. The meat was tender and moist. A lemon slice was provided and I squeezed the juice over the chicken. I also enjoyed dipping it into my friend's curry, which made it taste even better. I definitely want to hit up this truck again!
author: Helen H.

description:
I'm excited every Friday when I know JapaCurry is at Civic Center.  There's plenty of food trucks to try every Friday, but their curry is just so hard to resist.
The curry is very flavorful, a slight kick on the taste buds with mild spice.  I love their Chicken katsu.  Nicely breaded and crispy, it's delicious when drizzled with curry.  The Veggie croquette is very good too.  The breading is crunchy and the stuffing is delicious.  However, the portion is disappointing.  Only one croquette is given.
author: Karen L.

description: Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but I was not impressed. I got the daily special bento box - the main (salmon) was a tiny piece over lackluster rice. The cold fried chicken was soggy and the rest was a collection of undefined (some of which inedible) pickled things. Won't repeat.
author: Lucia W.

description:
After hearing all the hype circulating around the Japacurry truck, I decided to make the long journey to 1st and Howard during a lunch break. i took a 15 minute power walk to the japacurry truck with the vision of some damn good curry floating around in my head. we ordered a chicken katsu curry (nonspicy) and a pork katsu curry (spicy). 

maybe I just had such high expectations, or I walked too far and my stomach was just being a princess, but I don't know if japacurry was worth the hype. the food was good, but not love at first bite. it was enjoyable, but I felt like I could make the curry myself at home. oh and the spicy curry was not spicy at all, especially since the only difference between the spicy and non spicy were a couple of red pepper flakes floating around in the curry. the portion size is pretty good though, it was enough to have leftovers for the next day. 

i did like that the curry comes in a separate container so that you are able to allocate how much curry you want on your rice. it also prevents the katsu from becoming soggy while walking back to the office or to another place to eat.

they also offer bento boxes, but I didn't give them a second glance after seeing that they were pre-made and pretty small sized.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
A lesson in British: Savaloy - A highly seasoned sausage, usually red in color and found in Fish and Chip shops. Often also deep fried in batter.

It only took 20 month of first hearing about Japacurry for me to finally try it! Was it worth the wait? Eh.. undecided. If I had tried it a bit sooner then I would probably rate higher than the 3.5 stars I would now, this purely based on the other Katsu Curry's I have tried in the area. 
I finally chased Japacurry down at the Millbrae Japanese Culture Festival  and got the Chicken Katsu with an extra Sausage (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thAbNIGH1pWMi6uPw39e1w?select=EPwoKorEzyx1xgELEHGzCA#unZFZjHhNstJ5YyAJ3ovMg). I especially liked the Sausage which was soooo good! It actually tastes a lot like what I know to be called a ''Savaloy'' which is probably why I enjoyed it so much. The Curry sauce was plentiful and the Chicken ok, nice and crispy but a little too much coating for my liking. Pricing is fair and I would probably give them another try if I were to stumble upon them again, I just wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
OrderAhead is pretty much the best thing ever or else I would never have had the time with my break to come down to order and eat during the lunch rush.

I ordered the Chicken Katsu with veggies. The katsu was cooked to perfection. Chicken was tender inside and crispy on the outside. The medium spicy was a good amount of kick.  The only feedback I had were the frozen veggies.  I looks like it came out of the bag, so I wasn't impressed with that, but I still ate my veggies! 

Wish they weren't all the way down on Howard,  since it is a little walk for me, but it's ok, as long as I can order in advance.  

Curry done well. It will be a definite repeat!
author: Meshell C.

description: Lovely place to crab a quick lunch! I always get their bento boxes as it's very authentic and Japanese. Price is not cheap, but reasonable for that area. Plus, the portion is huge and the bentobox is packed with different and daily-rotating goodies. I always wonder how they even make a profit with such generous portions. Love it~
author: Sam C.

description: I love Japanese Curry, it is not spicy like the Indian and Thai Curry but rather sweet and spicy.  JapaCurry did not disappoint.  I always order the Chicken Katsu Curry.  The cutlet was breaded and fried to perfection.  I was expecting it to be soggy since I walked back to my office so I can eat it at my desk but it was still crispy and juicy not dry at all. They give you a generous portion of curry sauce in a separate plastic container so you can control the amount of curry you want to put over your rice or you can dip the chicken cutlets.  This is just genius.  They ask you if you want it spicy, I opt to get it medium spicy which gives it enough kick.  For 8 dollars you have a generous portion and a meal that truly satisfies!
author: Maria M.

description:
MMMmmmMMMMmm....

Chicken katsu was PARFECT. I don't care what other people say...if you like chicken karaage, then you will love the chicken katsu. Even my friends who got the pork katsu mentioned how delicious mine looked. 

The pumpkin croquette is overhyped, in my opinion. And, it's pretty awesome that they do LevelUp, otherwise, they only take cash.
author: Annie S.

description:
I've only been here twice, but now that I know it appears on Thursdays, a block from where I work, that number will definitely increase substantially.

I've tried their kara-age curry as well as their tonkatsu curry. Both are delicious and neither is particularly expensive ($8-9). Both are fried--tonkatsu is pork and kara-age is chicken--almost to perfection: just the right amount of crunch and not too oily. The curry, in all its sweet and salty perfection, is served in a separate container, but I suggest you pour the curry onto the protein and rice to achieve the optimal Japanese curry experience! They also provide a small container of pickled ginger, which adds a delightful sweetness.

The portions, I'd say, are just the right size: enough that you'll be satisfied, but not so large that you'll feel bloated. Optimal flavor and maximum post-lunch abdominal comfort! How could you possibly get more out of lunch?

The line can get a bit long, as with most popular food trucks in the city, but have no fear, for they are expedient in taking orders! The longest I've had to wait for is in the ballpark of 15-20 minutes. I usually despise long lines, but I gotta say, I'd wait 30 minutes for some delicious tonkatsu curry!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I definitely recommend trying this food truck, at least once if not way more! Even though the line is long, it does move quite fast. There are good choices to pick from - my favorites being the pork katsu & the vegetable curry option (which has a reallyy yummy fried pumpkin thing). The items aren't too expensive, but remember it's cash-only!

Go try it out!!!
author: Alice H.

description:
It's unclear as to how i've yet to write this place a review.  I'm a meat eater, and this place is heaven on Thursdays. 

You can see em start to set up shop at ~11AM, and they open for business around $11:30, and the hordes come hard and fast. If you don't want to wait 20-30 minutes for yo' food, getting there at 11:30 is a pretty good idea. 

In terms of meats/$$, i'd suggest getting either of the katsu curries instead of the karaage chiggen. But the Karaage is delicious, so get that sometimes too. Also add some vegetables to your curry for a dollar to obtain more pieces of the food pyramid. 

Oh ya, cash only, so don't say I didn't warn ya.
author: David C.

description:
Everyone likes JapaCurry. At least, if you don't, you're wrong. It's really good. People are always like "Muracci's is probably better" and stuff. Yeah, maybe? I haven't had Muracci's before, but if it's as good (or better) than JapaCurry I'd just also give it five stars. I thoroughly enjoy JapaCurry every time I eat it.

Pros:
- Their curry is delicious.
- Arbitrary spiciness (ask for "N" "s", where N is a number and s is the letter s, like "3S, please").
- Katsu is much fresher than most other katsu.
- You can get extra most anything. I usually get extra pickles, vegetables, and extra curry sauce. It adds up to an even $10 and is an incredibly filling meal.

Cons:
- The line is often a bit long.
- Cash only.
- Moves around downtown, so I only get it on Thursdays @ Mission and New Montgomery. Maybe this is a plus, since otherwise I'd probably get sick of it.
author: Michael B.

description:
Damn good Japanese curry. Definitely one of the best I've had across the US. If you have any appreciation for actual Japanese curry, not that Indian or Thai curry stuff, you will love this truck. How do you know they're legit? Owned and staffed by native Japanese, kind of reminds me of Saruno Burger truck.

To describe their curry sauce, there's a subtle sweetness to it as it blends with their house combination of spices, delivering mouth watering flavor as you mix it with their pork katsu, thinly fried to a light crisp. The spicy version by request is a bit hotter but don't go expecting some serious pepper action, this is Japanese comfort food after all.

Stick with the pork katsu, its the signature curry dish to get and if you have to stray, go with the chicken katsu. I'm not a fan of the karaage chicken just because by nature, it doesn't work too well with Japanese curry. For the completely unadventurous, I suppose you can try the bento boxes they now offer.

Also noticed today, they now started accepting LevelUp payments if you're looking to use a credit card.
author: Steven C.

description:
This truck always have long lines for their food.  Not to mention, the word 'SOLD OUT' across the menu.  So, you better get there early before everything gets snapped up.  But then again... 

Here's my experience...

The first time I went, I got there at 11:30am.  I wanted to make sure I got my first choice of menu.  I ordered the tofu and veggie bento box.  I walked back to my job to eat it at my desk (that's 1.5 blocks away).  By the time I got back, the food was completely cold.  It was not good at all.  The flavors were either too salty or too bland.  Blah!  I vowed never to order the bento again.

Today I went for the 2nd time, I said, I'll order the curry this time.  But the special caught my eye and I was HUNGRY!  So, I ordered the special bento box - salmon, cali roll, karage chicken and curry flavored potato croquette.  After I got back to the office, AGAIN, the food was cold, which leads me to believe it was cold to begin with.  I ate a very salty salmon, mushy chicken karage, cold rice and lots of extremely salty pickled veggies.  (I'm sooo thirsty as I type right now!)

I can only offer up a 2 star, I would downgrade it to 1 star since I really didn't enjoy eating their food at all!!!  But the extra star goes to their usage of LevelUp application on smartphone, I got $1 discount from my meal today.  And the staff was very friendly.  I'm also not going to write them off yet because I still need to try their curry.  After all, their whole purpose for the truck is to sell curry, hence their biz name, "JapaCurry"...duh!

To be continued...
author: Jenny T.

description: Chicken katus curry is perfect and yes it is fried stuff but very very tasty and worth ignoing the fat piece. ;) U will always find some ppl in line but service is fast and must go place.
author: Ashwani K.

description: One of the most efficient trucks in town. Even though the line is usually super long, mainly because the Pork and Chicken Tonkatsu with curry are one of the best lunches you can get from a truck, they are super fast serving everyone.
author: Antonio H.

description:
3.5 stars.

Had it at OTG, good portions for the price, just like getting it at a restaurant portion! Had the pork katsu curry since the chicken one was all out. It was a dish that taste how it should, nothing too special, but it's worth a try for curiosity sake. This was such a warm dish, a great alternative to hapa ramen, which is overly priced for such a small portion!

From reading the review on the other JapaCurry (they should just have one page to review), I'm probably going to come back for the kurobuta sausage curry.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Soooo good.

The boy&I were craving Japanese Curry, and we've been into food trucks lately, so we decided to visit JapaCurry! The line was super long, but the service was relatively quick. It took maybe 15-20 min from the time I lined up to the time I got my food, which wasn't bad at all. We went right after the tsunami disaster, and they were donating 10% of proceeds to Japan, which I thought was really nice of them.

The food itself? Yummmm. We ordered an extra scoop of rice&just split one order, and I must say, it's definitely worth it. I know I say this a lot, but I really don't eat much, so it was the perfect amount for two people. The chicken katsu was done perfectly, and the mild sauce had so much flavor. Definitely coming back next time I'm craving curry.
author: Amy L.

description:
Found them at SF Tofu Festival yesterday! My sister had their katsu curry before and she said it's very good. Crispy katsu, she said. We approached the truck. Odd thing about the truck at the festival is they only had 2 menu items: ramen burger with beef patty or tofu patty. So, we went, 'oh, are they trying something new?' Then, as we were in front of the truck contemplating if we should try it, a guy (the line organizer) came over and said, 'today, the wait is only 10 minutes. We had customers waited for 2 hours to get one and they said it's worth it.' Fell into the trap. We only wanted to get one to try it since we know Hawaiian L&L at financial district also has it. It wouldn't be $8 a burger there! But, my sister convinced me to get 2 because what if it's good. So, we ordered 2 ramen burgers with beef patty since we had wanted to try one for a long time (They ran out of the tofu patty one). Disappointing. The burger is small. No wonder people ordered 2 per person (dude, $16 for 2 burgers per person. Eating a gourmet burger at some other place is more worth it). The ramen and patty are bland. It is soy-glazed, but seriously, we couldn't taste the glaze until half-way. So, they were also selling custom sriracha for $5 a bottle, but they have some bottles laying around for people to try. If the sriracha had not been there, paying $8 for the burger would have been painful. So, since it's bland, we asked the guy if we could try it on the top of the burger. He said yeah go for it. Glad we did. We got a squirt of it and walked away. It's more tasteful. 
Anyway, we suspected the burger came from Hawaiian L&L because we saw some boxes labeled 'ramen burger.' But, JapaCurry apparently got truck-jacked by Keizo (based in New York, only 3 stars on Yelp). Disappointed.
author: Ervi L.

description:
The best chicken katsu curry I've had thus far!

I came upon JapaCurry at OTG McCoppin and knew right away that I had to try something from them! Of course, I ended up getting the chicken katsu with spicy curry over white rice for $8. 

The chicken was cooked perfectly and the spicy curry sauce was oh so good! I drenched my whole plate with it! I love how they give you more than enough sauce. I can't wait to get my hands on it again!
author: Fallon P.

description:
I tried their Daily Special Bento Box.
Great authentic Makuno-uchi style bento box for $10.
If I don't feel like walking down to Delica, I will definitely buy their bento box again.
(Congrats for opening up Izakaya Roku!!)
author: Sunny S.

description: I very much enjoyed my recent lunch at the JapaCurry truck while they were parked on Pine & Sansome not too long ago.  My Japanese co-worker and I ordered separate curry dishes- he had the veggie croquettes, and I had tonkatsu.  The dishes were reasonably priced, well-packed, and tasted great when we returned to our office 10 minutes later.  The portions were sizable but not overwhelming.  While we ordered their 'spicy' option, neither of us felt they were very spicy at all- flavorful however.  My coworker commented that other than the spice, the dish was quite similar to curry he orders frequently in Tokyo.  Anyways, this truck made a great first impression and it will be in my rotation- I'll be back for more for sure.
author: Andy S.

description:
Perhaps a little late to the game among my coworkers but my more recent discovery of JapaCurry has made me a fan.

I usually get the chicken katsu with spicy curry. I ask for no rice (low-carb diet) and so instead of rice they give me some delicious veggies. I haven't tried anything else on the menu yet and I always fear opting for something else and missing out on the katsu - perhaps one day.

Some pro-tips: 
1. Find their location on Twitter. 
2. Bring Cash. 
3. Go past 12:30 to avoid the lines.
author: Farid H.

description:
Five stars for this cash-only Japanese food truck. I swear, every Thursday my entire team at work comes here for lunch. Every single Thursday, and we pretty much get the same thing every time too. It's that good.

The line can be long around noon, but we've also gone at 11 or 1 and there's typically no line. If you want a bento box, you can skip the line and order right away but I've never gotten one so I can't really vouch for that. The chicken katsu curry is my staple here.

This is also a great place if you like your food spicy. You can specify the spice level by telling them the number of "S" you want in your food, like "Chicken Katsu Curry 4S". The highest I've seen anyone get is 8S, but I'm totally a spice wimp so I've never gone higher than 4S. If you just say "spicy" they'll give you 1S, so be more specific if you want your food spicy!

If you don't like spicy food, don't worry! Just tell them that and you can still enjoy the delicious Japanese curry.
author: Nikhil S.

description: Quick, tasty and affordable! Perfect for lunch in the financial district. Highly recommend! They have curry and bento boxes during lunch.
author: Ally T.

description: I love this place! I don't always get curry and usually opt tor a bento box (no waiting since they're prepackaged). I used to always get the tofu but now try for the daily special since it comes with so many different items. Get there early it always sells out! I even brought one home for my dad (who was born in Japan) and now he won't get bentos from anywhere else (ie Nijiya). I try to go at least once a few times a month & bring bentos home for the fam. Oishii!
author: Laurie E.

description:
Substandard Japanese food, at least speaking of Katsu.
Quite bland. I would expect something better from a food truck.
author: Piotr G.

description:
When it comes to Japanese curry for lunch, I usually find myself making the hike down towards Kearny to get Muraccis. While Japacurry has been making the rounds near my work for about a year now, I usually prefer to get Muraccis over this due to the slightly larger portions and the awesome katsu they serve over there. However, Japacurry has added something to their menu that, while not served everyday, truly gives me a reason to come here. That item is their Chicken Kara-age Curry. For those unfamiliar with Chicken Kara-age, it's essentially the equivalent of some delicious chicken nuggets. Now top that off with the delicious curry sauce and you've got yourself a winner. 

While you can't go wrong with either Japacurry or Muraccis as both are delicious options, definitely give this place a shot if you haven't tried it before. And should you see the Kara-age special on the menu, order it without hesitation as it does sell out quite fast, a clear sign that something is probably quite delicious!
author: Gajan K.

description:
Randomly stumbled across this truck while blindly looking for something different to eat in the financial district. I love Japanese curry so much that I didn't even bother to look up reviews before I sprinted across the street (nearly getting mowed down by a car sporting the now omnipresent pink moustache) to place my order, because after all, even if Japanese curry is bad, it's still good, you know?

Anyway, the curry here isn't bad, it's damned good even. I like the karaage, but the katsu is really well done too, crunchy on the outside but still moist on the inside. The option to order more pickles is appreciated and the croquettes are also delicious. "Spicy" isn't really spicy, but it's Japanese food so I don't really expect it to be. I first went here when it was parked on Mission, near First, but since then I've seen it a few blocks away from Muracci's, which is awesome because that line is  always atrocious but there's never much of a wait here.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Found the truck at 1st and Howard the other day, and had the Chicken Katsu Curry. Delicious, filling, and un-fussy. They're even kind enough to keep the curry apart from the fried chicken, which lets you find a place to sit and mix at your own pace. The curry is delicious and has a depth of flavor akin to a good Mexican mole. I'm definitely coming back.

There was a line of 20-30 people when we arrived, but it only took 10-15 minutes to get our food. Fast and friendly service - can't beat it.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Love this place. For lunch break, this is a hot spot. I love to come here when I meet up with friends or co-workers. I recommend this truck for people who love japanese curry especially with rice. I've had muracci's several times before, and I'd personally think muracci's is slightly better, but not better enough that I won't ever go to JapaCurrytruck (in my personal opinion). I still keep coming to both places because they are both worth going to. If you haven't had JapaCurry Truck, then it's worth deciding for yourself.

Line can get pretty long around 12. So come early (11:30 when truck opens)

I can't say I've ordered other items, so the 5 stars goes to just to spicy chicken katsu curry, pork katsu, and sausages. Never tried the bento boxes.

WARNING: cash only!
author: Fred S.

description:
The $8 plate of katsu with spicy curry is worth the wait. Not only is the curry rich and spicy, but the portions are generous enough that you'll have at least a second meal in store.

I showed up at 12:20 and waited about twenty minutes. I walk by the corner all the time around the lunch hour, and there is *always* a line. I suppose you could drop by before noon if you were really wait-averse.
author: Bill H.

description: JapaCurry has become something of a weekly tradition around the workplace, but despite having it every week and planning to have it in the future, I can't really grade it beyond three stars. The curry is fairly good, especially with some spice, but the meat is pretty low quality. The prices are not much better than any other downtown takeout place and the truck does not accept credit cards. You can also pretty much expect to wait in line for quite a while as the truck is very popular. Overall, it is simply good enough but not outstanding in any way.
author: Michael H.

description: I ordered the chicken Katsu with a mild spicy curry and it turned out good! Nommies. I'd catch this truck on a Tuesday again.
author: Yennie L.

description:
Should have read the yelp reviews..place would have gotten a 4 star..but 3 will do until next time.
Usually pass by this truck when I go to Target on my lunch break at work to buy stuff.. Always see a LONG line.. 
Today was interesting, after Target I wanted Chipotle but the line in that place was Chipocray. So while walking back I saw this place with NO LINE!!! Its like baby jesus knew I was hungry and answered my prayers!!

I was STOKED and order the Karaage (come on fried chicken and rice..LEEEEGGGOOO). The man asked me you want it spicy and i was like HELLSSS YEEEAHHH..

Of course the deets, cash only, food came out QUICK!!! I was super happy to take this to my desk and grub out! The Karaage was great, light, flavorful and juicy..couldn't go wrong. The curry had a nice flavor to it and it was nice they put it in a seperate container. The biggest mistake I made was not yelping before ordering..sigh such a cardinal sin..for shame for shame! #nevereatbeforeyelping

Had I have known the spice system I would def gotten 4S or even more. When he told me spicy I was ready for spicy tantalizing zing to be lingering on my tongue. But spicy is not spicy AT ALL!

All in all solid place, will try again and see if the upped spice level will deliver..until next time japacurry!
author: Johnny G.

description:
Pork katsu is one of those amazing foods that you totally don't realize is amazing until you try it.

So what are you waiting for? Stop reading this and go hunt the truck down!

Katsu is a thin cutlet that gets fried in a tempura-sorta batter (panko crubs are in it I think) and then in the case of the wonder JapaCurry truck, gets combined with wonderful curry sauce.

Yum! This is a super filling lunch and its very reasonably priced..... so worth it, I can't even begin to describe!

They have other stuff too.... but I don't care. Get the Pork Katsu Curry. It rocks.
author: Peter M.

description:
Had their teriyaki chicken last week - I get that it's a pre-made bento, so it being cold didn't bother me much.  But the chicken was dry and rubbery, and the whole thing was covered in sauce, which was thick and way too salty.  So salty that I had to throw it out half way through.

I'll be sticking with medium hot curry and chicken katsu (pork katsu can be dry sometimes), with vegetables ($1 extra).  Those are solid.
author: Kris L.

description:
JapaCurry catered a casual 60-70 person party I hosted (without the food truck) and they were perfect. I was a little worried that the trays of fried chicken katsu would arrive soggy but everything was warm and crisp. Small details that I appreciate:

 * Arrived on time (even though the location was tricky)
 * Arrived with two people to expedite setup
 * Easy to work with over email; responded quickly and had no problem with small adjustments
 * The food was fantastic!
 * Delivered under my initial budget

I'd definitely work with these folks again.
author: Elaine W.

description:
JapaCurry does some pretty delicious curry. I would recommend it if you're in the mood for tasty fried pork cutlet/chicken kara-age. Not to mention some nice warm curry to top it off.

This place can get crowded, but they turn the line around quick. Nice staff, convenient, reasonable prices! Not much you can ask for from SF food trucks!

CASH ONLY. So be ready to make it rain/mist.
author: Jason T.

description:
Thursday mornings aren't the most productive for me at work. From the time I get in until lunch, there's not much I can think about other than the JapaCurry truck that'll be right outside at 11:30.

The line can get ridiculously long, but moves pretty quickly. You can avoid the line entirely if you're there before noon.

Potato and pumpkin croquette curry is my dish of choice. I can't get over how good the pumpkin is. Yum.

I usually go with three spicies (3S). The number of spicies is just the number of spicy powder packets they add to your individual curry, so your curry will come with red powder on top that they just put in.

The 'potato' used to be potato wedges, but they've changed it to fries. I'd rather they change back, but this isn't enough to make me budge on the five stars.

Cash only!
author: Greg A.

description:
One look at the JapaCurry truck and it's hard not to have a fondness for the food already. The design of it is just so fun and inviting! Prob the happiest truck I've ever seen and there are a lot of good ones.

The truck was located at 420 Howard on a weds. I showed up about 12:10 and the line wasn't too bad. Prob got my food in 15 to 20 minutes.

I went with the Katsu Curry (Spicy) with a side of sausage. The curry sauce came in another container and I took great pleasure pouring it all over the rice and meat. Probably the most enjoyable part of the meal. The pork was cooked very well. Breading to meat ratio was adequate. I was kind of disappointed in the quantity of meat they gave me. I looked over at my friends box and he seemed to get more. Maybe it was because i ordered a side of sausage? I hope not because that's a major jip. I thought the sausage was just ok, didn't think it was particularly flavorful for a 'high quality' sausage. All in all the actual curry sauce is very tasty and top notch, and altho it wasn't as spicy as I wanted it, japanese spicy is not supposed to be deathly.  They put some love into that curry, no doubt about it.

The question remains, how does this compare to Marucci's? It's comparable. I think overall I prefer the meat at Muracci's but the curry sauce I give an ever so slight advantage to JapaCurry. Not that I'm refusing to declare a definitive winner, but I call it a wash. Can't go wrong with both.
author: Jack C.

description:
Everytime japacurry parked their truck close to my office area, half of my firm starts to line up for it. 

I usually get their chicken katsu curry. As much as I like pork, their pork katsu is much less tender than chicken. Their curry sauce is very thick and flavorful. The serving size is huge enough to give me severe food coma. 

Get a punchcard from them and you can get the 12th japacurry for free :D
author: Ruxin H.

description: I got the karaage curry (spicy) and the curry sandwich. The curry was good albeit standard and unspectacular. A good amount of spiciness. The chicken was very juicy and flavorful. For the inevitable comparison to Muracci's, the quality is similar but I feel like Muracci's gives slightly bigger portions. The reason I give this place a 5 is the amazing curry sandwich. Perfectly breaded on the outside and filled with curry. Much better than the Muracci's equivalent and a must get if you go here.
author: Kevin T.

description:
I've seen the JapaCurry Truck parked in front of Blackrock on Howard many Wednesdays before. But I never brought myself to buy anything before. 

But the other day as I was contemplating on going to John's Snack and Deli and buying either a kimchee burrito or some krn sushi rolls, I happened to walk past the JapaCurry truck again and happened to see a HUGE queue. And just like that, I got in line even though I wasn't feeling very "curry".

I ordered the katsu chicken (spicy) and it was pretty good. :) I would recommend not pouring curry over the chicken because then it won't be as crunchy.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
I LOVE the dark meat chicken part of the chicken katsu curry. It's juicy, tender, fatty and oozing with oil-fried goodness. 

However, I'm not a fan of the curry. For a truck titled JapaCURRY, I'd expect the curry sauce to be the highlight. Unfortunately that's not the case with this truck. Muracchi's makes a much more enticing pot of curry and is available everyday of the week. 

If you're into curries predominately for the meat, then definitely give Japacurry a try. Otherwise, head to Muracchi's for your curry cravings. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!

P.S. The truck is in Fidi on Fridays
author: Priya S.

description:
Line gets long quick, so get there early.

Food is great and a good price. I'd recommend a bento box if you don't want to wait too long, but I prefer the curry.
author: Kyle K.

description:
My heart was fluttering as i was walking down Market street holding a box of spicy curry with rice and chicken katsu...I was wondering if all the people i was walking by knew how excited i was about my lunch...

I got back to my desk and devoured it!

JapaCurry did not disappoint. The chicken was breaded and fried so that it's crispy; but the meat was still tender and juicy. I ordered my curry spicy and it had a slight hint of spicyness. I also love that the curry is in a separate container so that the chicken katsu does not get soggy. I can't wait to try the kurobuta sausage curry next!
author: Terry C.

description:
First time trying this truck and I enjoy Curry so I had high hopes, however I didn't try their curry dishes as I was enticed by the $10 Special Bento box. It was pre-made, which made it very quick for a lunch on the go. Came with three sushi rolls, a square container salad, rice with a piece of salmon and seaweed on top, a couple of pieces of chicken and a mystery item that I don't recall what it was. Nothing stood out in taste, but it was decent and filling.

I know next time I will be trying the chicken katsu curry. I'm sure that will change my mind about this truck, but for now I gotta go with what I've tried and know.
author: Norman L.

description:
The lovely Jen D was kind enough to help score me some veggie JapaCurry today at Off the Grid (while I waited in line for delicious bao buns).

Starving from our fast paced walk over to Civic Center, I was excited to learn that unlike the itty bitty bao buns I was bringing back for my co-workers, JapaCurry's curry is the perfect serving.

I dived into well cooked rice, topped off with an array of formidable tender vegetables, and a delightful slightly spiced curry sauce. Each spoonful made me smile. It reminded me of eating curry when I used to live in Japan.

And yes, the classic slightly cheesy Jessica comment - JapaCurry was packed with love and care. 

Though I don't know if it's worth the crazy wait (if hyped waiting isn't your thing - check out Delica or Muracci's curry) - which often follows it  - I would highly recommend checking out JapaCurry when you get a chance, and when the line is bearable.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Simple home cooked food at its best.

The tonkatsu is fried just right with a lightly breaded crispy skin and tender pork underneath. The curry sauce is thick, well-spiced, and has a lot of different layers of tastes. The rice is perfectly sticky and a great vessel for the sauce. Pickles rounded it up and made it a perfect dish.

It's a great Japanese curry option in the city, and certainly a step ahead of the competition. The only problem I have is that the truck doesn't travel down to the peninsula! ;)
author: Alice C.

description:
JapaCurry was one of the reasons we went to Off the Grid yesterday in McCoppin. I've heard of this Japanese Food Truck a couple of months ago when they first opened and I've been dying to find it and try it out. Unfortunately when we got to McCoppin the truck was at the end of their shift and they only had one choice from their menu. Fortunately it was the Chicken Katsu Curry which was what I was craving for all along. 

The Katsu came with White Rice and the Curry sauce on a separate container. After eating some of the other food from the other Food Trucks I took my time and made sure I had enough room in me to chow down what turned out to be a pretty big serving. The chicken was properly breaded and crispy as it can be and the White Rice was well made. The Curry was the mystery but as soon as I opened the container my mouth started to water, I love the smell of Curry (my wife and sister-in-law hates curry so they didn't want any part of it). The Curry had both spicy and sweetness to it which worked very well for me. I'm still craving for it right now as I type this review. HHHMMMM! 

I'm a little disappointed I didn't get to try more from their menu, like the Kurobuta Sausage Curry (Berkshire pork) or the Nori Bento Box (fried fish, fish cake, & dried seaweed over rice). I am definitely looking forward to seeing this truck again, I think it's one of the usual Food Trucks that shows up at the Off the Grid happening. Also love the orange and 70s cartoon décor on the truck, very easy to distinguished from the other trucks.
author: Mel B.

description:
If you are a fan of Japanese Curry, what is better than one on wheels?  
 
Whenever I am at a Japanese curry joint, I always order the pork katsu. It was perfectly crispy without the meat getting overcooked or the batter too fried. Most people do not like the red colored pickled cabbage/turnip looking thing that comes as a side, but I love it! It does not have a overpowering vinegar taste.  
 
The curry comes in a separate tube while the pork, rice, and side cabbage is in a brown box to-go box.  Some people like to dip their meat in the curry. I personally like to pour the curry on top of my rice and pork katsu. Their site conveniently tells you which days and street it would most likely be parked on. The brown truck is easy to spot. One of my favorites when it  comes to food trucks! 
 
Beware: you may smell afterwards from the curry!
author: Becky Q.

description:
This is one food truck that had gotten it figured out.  The line was long, but efficient.  I had my order within 10 minutes of waiting in line.  Big bonus!

We had the tonkatsu [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thAbNIGH1pWMi6uPw39e1w?select=1SyTMT-4bSGcSElJY4EhWQ] and the kurobuta sausage [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thAbNIGH1pWMi6uPw39e1w?select=KBmKoRKlz2dcQC5NovqvWg] with spicy curry.  The tonkatsu was cooked to perfection.  Crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside.  Wish we had more than three sausages in the other dish, but it was extremely filling nonetheless.

The spice on the curry had just enough heat without being overbearing.  You're not going to sweat eating it, but it will definitely warm you up on a cold day.

Got my frequent buyer's card, so get ready for my return!
author: Jenny L.

description: There are better curry places in this area than the Japacurry truck.  The meat was bland even after smothering it in their sauce.  And "spicy" means they just sprinkle a tiny bit of chili pepper to the regular sauce.  Not impressed.  Curry wasn't great, but kind of good.  Meh.
author: Chris C.

description:
Thank you JapaCurry Truck for overcoming the hateration from brick & mortar business owners, such as Allison Rowe, who were acting quite [word that rhymes with runty].  I love me some Japanese curry and up until now Muracci's has been my only outlet.  The curry here tastes slightly more complex and homemade, but I'll still fall back to Muracci's for days when the truck can't find parking.

Kurobuta Sausage Curry: So basically Kurobuta is just the Japanese term for a Berkshire pig, Britain's oldest pig and probably second only to the Ibérico pig.  Three small sausages that are both snappy and fatty at the same time.  Perfect richness to contrast the spice-filled curry.  And wow, what a curry!!!  Even mediocre Japanese curry is pretty good (yes, I mean you Golden Curry) so this homemade curry is purely amazing!  The white rice was a little soggy and boring, but I devoured all of it like it was fine Afghani pulao since this curry had to be finished.

Veggie Croquette Curry: A very nice croquette with a mushy sweet potato filling surrounded by the typical mashed potatoes and crispy outside.  I feel they were a bit stingy on the portion.  Tubers are cheap so why only give one medium sized croquette sliced in two?  I may have to stick to the meat going forward...  The curry sauce was nice, though this was vegan (as opposed to the beef-based one with my sausage) so it wasn't as gelatinous since it was missing the yummy fat/marrow.
author: Adam B.

description:
The people are nice, the line moves fairly fast, but the food was underwhelming. 

I have seen this truck at various spots around Mission & New Montgomery and of course, there's always a line. That right there is enough to suck me in. Long line must = good food. 

I arrived right after noon, which was bad timing on my part, and when I saw the line I almost left. But those smells drew me in. Fried goodness & curry, what a wonderful combo! 

I ordered the spicy chicken katsu. I'd say my total wait time was less then 30 minutes (better than Sushirrito!). Every katsu order comes with a box containing rice & your chicken or pork cutlet, plus a large container of curry sauce. I love that they give you more sauce than you might need. The spicy sauce wasn't too spicy, but I did find that I was sniffling an awful lots towards the end of my meal. I guess the spice caught up with me! The chicken itself was a bit too fatty IMO. Plus I would have liked it to be cooked a bit more. Maybe I'm just being picky but I wasn't totally thrilled with my meal. I think I'll try the vegetarian option next time. 

**Side note: I totally support the food trucks & their right to serve food to the people of SF. Therefore, I give a big FU to the owner of Harvest & Rowe for complaining to the city about the JapaCurry truck being parked near her business. I won't be patronizing that restaurant anymore.
author: Erin S.

description:
My new favorite food truck in the SF mobile food scene.

I've had a chance to try the chicken katsu curry as well as the tonkatsu curry.  Both are very good, though I think the chicken katsu is slightly better.  Both are breaded very well and have that excellent crunchy exterior while still maintaining moist and flavorful meats inside.  The curry is also very tasty.  I'm no Japanese curry aficionado, but the curry served here tastes very similar to that of Indian curries.  I'm not complaining however, it's delicious.  Spicy also isn't really that spicy.

They also do a very efficient job of taking orders and turning them around getting your food to you very quickly which is essential in the mobile food vendor scene.
author: Erich D.

description:
Finger licking, or should I say plate licking good Japanese curry can be found at the new mobile food truck that debuted this evening at OTG: Fort Mason.  They started simple, with four types of curry ($6 - $7) served from huge silver vats.  The curry comes with steamed white rice and Japanese pickles.

Menu:
* Pork katsu curry
* Chicken katsu curry
* Kurobuta sausage curry
* Vegetable croquette curry

The truck seemed to have cute illustrations but it was too dark to fully appreciate them. 

The sausage curry ($7) came with three smoky, juicy, scored Kurobuta sausage links. The curry was thicker (which I liked) with tiny bits of meat. It's quite sweet, deep in flavor, not too salty - tastes like the curry has been cooking for hours.  So good. The curry gets cold quickly.

Unlike many of the vendors at OTG, their portions are enough for a meal (vs. a small snack). A delicious addition to the mobile food scene.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I always wanted to try this truck but never had the time or I got something else for lunch.  Anyway, rather than hiking to the nearest Japanese place (Tokyo Express), I dropped by the JapaCurry truck today.  After debating whether I should try the Nori bento or chicken teri, I got the chicken teri with a side of pumpkin croquette. 

The meat and croquette was hot but the rice was rock cold. Any self respecting Asian likes their rice hot -- unless it's sushi (which this isn't).  No worries, I popped the sucker into the microwave and nuked the food into submission.

The croquette was good. No stuffing in it ala Sushi Bay but good nevertheless.  Chick teri was yummy as well.  For $8 it is filling.  Portion isn't humongous but you will be full after you inhale the whole bento.

Guess I will try the Nori Bento after all...
author: Wendy H.

description:
Food trucks are so overrated.

And so overpriced, considering it's from a god damn truck.

In every other country, street food is cheap. I mean really cheap. Yet in modern day America, it's not cheap at all. It's not expensive, but it's comparable to restaurants that cater to the take out crowd. Which food trucks basically do, but without having all of the expenses and regulatory requirements of a real brick and mortar restaurant.

With that said, I finally tried Japacurry. I've walked by it a million times over on Mission/2nd, but never felt compelled to try it. I was planning to go to get a sandwich, but the thought of curry intrigued me. So I walked up and ordered a karaage curry, surrendered 8 bucks, and was on my way. Found a nice place to sit and though the food was decent. Not bad, not great, but just decent.

The karaage was a bit tough and stringy and each piece was far too large to be a mouthful. Do not plan on looking elegant while eating this, as you will need to bite pieces off with your teeth, because they don't supply plastic knives. The stringiness of the chicken doesn't help. Flavor was just fine, however.

The curry was just okay. I asked for spicy, and they basically just sprinkle more chile pepper powder on it. It wasn't bad, and it will definitely satisfy a curry craving, but it was really quite ordinary.

Oddly, they served a bed of shredded cabbage with the rice and karaage, which I thought was strange. Shredded cabbage is often served with tonkatsu, but never with katsu curry. I ordered karaage, which is even stranger with cabbage. Perhaps they're confused, or maybe just creative. Ha. I don't find the cabbage to be objectionable, but thought I'd mention this just cuz.

Not sure if I'll be back. Much better options in the city. For $8, it was a decent deal, but that's pretty much what you'd pay in a real restaurant, so don't think you'll be saving money just because it's from a truck.
author: J K.

description: To be honest, I was a little annoyed at first because the truck changed locations within the hour, but once I got there right at noon in just a short line, I was relieved. The food comes out fast too, which makes sense since they've got the lunch items premade. All the food came out painfully hot. I had the pumpkin croquette meal and the boy had the pork katsu meal, each comes with a container of curry. I am so glad that the curry came in separated containers and not poured over the croquette or katsu because I was afraid the paper container would've be soaked through and the fried goodies would've become soggy. The curry itself was so, so good delicious. I loved it. It was the best part. The potato croquette was much too sweet and small. The rest of my box was filled with veggies. The pork katsu was good too, sliced thinly and fried to a golden crisp.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Love it!  

My co-worker and I arrived there around 11:45 am and there were about 10 people in front of us already.  But don't worry, the line moved pretty fast and so do the food too.

I got the Katsu Curry Chicken with brown rice ($8.00 plus $0.50 brown rice ).  OMG....It was so tasty!  The batter was perfectly fried.  The meat was tender and juicy.  The curry was little bit on the watery side but the taste was pretty good.  The portion was great too.  It could fill you up the whole day!  

I think in terms of the quality of the food and service from a food truck, this is the best place I have ever tried.
author: Liza T.

description: I am a sucker for food trucks. But I haven't had JapaCurry until just a few weeks ago. I normally wouldn't be interested in curry, but my coworker was heading here to grab lunch and I tagged along. AM I GLAD I DID! $8 for chicken katsu curry! Portion was a good amount, enough to fill me up. So I was extremely satisfied. Also, I believe this is the first time I've had Japanese Curry.
author: Lina C.

description:
If it wasn't for that pumpkin croquette, I would not walk a mile in heels looking for this food truck. Okay, I would not walk a mile in heels looking for these because I hide flip flops in my purse. And if it wasn't for the sausage, then I would be alone on my journey. 

What is the pumpkin croquette good? It's somewhat like a huge Japanese hash brown, but it's creamy and smooth on the inside. Moreover, the croquette taste like fall and has a good golden fried texture. 

Why is the sausage good? I don't know. I have yet to try it. But my lunch buddy claims it just is. But for now, I will stick to the pumpkin croquette. 

Lastly, the curry itself alone is good because it fragrant and addicting. This is probably due to the countless hours that it is slow cooked. Plus, there is a spicy version for those extra cold days. 

This may be good Japanese comfort food, but it makes me nostalgic about my college days when my friends and I go searching for curry in West LA.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
I was mortified when someone told me about JapaCurry and I had never heard of it. Of course, I quickly looked it up and decided I was going to hunt this truck down. 

I got there around noon and there was already a growing line, but it went fairly quickly. I had the chicken katsu curry while my cousin had the kurobuta sausage. I really liked that the curry was put in a separate container and they offered a spicy version of it. The food was really good and hearty. We were approached by a photographer from the Wall Street Journal who had asked if she can take pictures of us. Well, of course you can! (Yes, pictures of us stuffing our faces made it into Thursday's WSJ edition) 

There was a lot of curry, so I took the rest home thinking about using it for udon. I ended up using it as a dip for rice chips. Needless to say, not only was the curry delicious over chicken and rice, but it's equally as good with chips.
author: Adelina W.

description:
This was five stars for me when I first had it, but not anymore. This is mostly due to the large variance in curry quality (cuality?) they seem to have going on.

The wait here is long, but not terrible. You can usually walk up to the line and leave curried in less than 20 minutes. 

As mentioned above, the quality here is extremely varied. I've had the tonkatsu and chicken katsu several times, and they've ranged from moist and delicious to bland and dry. Important to note that they usually hit somewhere closer to the moist/delicious end of the spectrum.

The volume and heat of the curry also seems to change every time I come. I go for 3x spicy, which sometimes means pretty mild and sometimes means a stomach ulcer. 

At the end of the day it's fried meat, so you're not going to have a bad time. I still come here pretty frequently to chase my first curry high- and I'd recommend you give it a try too.
author: Ryan D.

description: The daily bento is 50% of the reason I make it into work on Fridays... amazing and definitely worth looking forward to at the end of the week :)
author: Clarissa P.

description: I like their curry, the portion is big, usually can't finish it. I always tend to have pumpkin croquette curry because it comes with vegetables. I wish they have half meat/half veggie option. Anyway, happened to have their nori-ben once around 11 AM and realized it's super popular and sell out fast. In Japan, nori-ben is very common and well-known for the cheapest bento box option, but I guess it's quite unusual here.
author: Yoko S.

description:
UPDATED TO REMOVE ANGST

It's decent. Not the best but good. Sometimes you can get screwed on the meat portions (especially with the kara-age chicken), but usually enough to put you in a decent food coma. I recommend asking for a half portion of rice - makes the curry sauce go a longer distance without paying extra for more sauce (the rice is filler anyways). If you like spicy you can give a spice number and they'll add spice to the sauce. The bento boxes are pretty good and varied.
author: Garrett D.

description:
Tried JapaCurry at Off the Grid in SF.  They had a special - katsu curry burrito - chicken or pork katsu, curry, rice, lettuce, cheese, sour cream, pickled ginger.

I'm all for fusion foods, but this missed the mark for me.  The slight sweetness of the tortilla, curry, and ginger plus the pretty neutral flavors of rice, cheese, and lettuce made for an overall flat experience.  That being said, the pork katsu itself was delicious.  If I'm ever at this truck again, I'll just be getting a plate of that.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Japa Curry Truck stops right outside my work on Tuesdays...how convenient! They must know I crave their Chicken Katsu over rice with curry ($8) everrrry Tuesday. 

Portions are generous. Enough for lunch and then I usually save half for Wednesday's lunch. The katsu is perfectly cooked and crispy which softens up a bit with the curry on top. 

I've somehow only ordered the Chicken Katsu so far which is unlike me since I like trying new things. But it's just SO GOOD. The bento boxes are cheaper ($6-$7) and I may venture out of my katsu safe zone someday. 

Japa Curry is the best. I love it. And it loves me.
author: Christine A.

description:
I enjoyed my meal from this spot.

I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry over Rice and it was delicious and satisfying.  The chicken was moist and tender on the inside and nice and crispy outside.  The curry itself is flavorful and fresh-tasting - a good balance of spicy, sweet and savory.  As with a lot of food trucks, it's a bit on the pricey side ($8), but worth it.  

While I wouldn't say it was absolutely fantastic and not really worth the wait longer than 5 minutes, it's very good food.
author: Ken G.

description:
JapaCurry, I love you so much.

I heard about this gem from Off the Grid and a coworker who follows all the yummy food trucks in SF.  We found out they were coming to Mission and New Montgomery and made plans to go.  We expected a line so thankfully we allotted time to deal with the line...good thing too because when we got there, it was packed!

I ordered the chicken katsu based on reviews and got a mild curry.  Upon coming back to the office I tore into it like I hadn't eaten in days.  It was...awesome.  Tasty katsu chicken with no nasty grease-bites, fluffy white rice, and some of the tastiest curry I'd ever had.  I had leftover curry, which I saved in the fridge for consumption later on.  I happily spent the rest of my afternoon in a food coma.

The service was very fast and they were super friendly.  I got the stamp card which I will definitely be putting to good use.  If you have the chance to try JapaCurry, go early as they apparently sold out!  I will definitely be trying you again this week, JapaCurry!
author: Sonya T.

description:
Got the infamous pork katsu with the recommended spicy curry for $8!

They give you lots of rice & katsu, enough for two meals for sure. I love how they pack the curry separately in another plastic container so that the curry doesn't get the rice or katsu all soggy. 

The spicy curry, however, is NOT spicy - putting a few sprinkles of spicy curry on top doesn't make it spicy... The katsu is nothing special -- it was soft and the batter wasn't overly fried or soggy, but it's just subpar. Rice was the good Japanese kind, which means it was wholesome, fluffy, and a bit chewy. However, I felt like this was something I could have made at home, and don't really see what the hype is about :/ 

TIP: Come at 11:50 AM to avoid ANY line!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Great Japanese Curry.  I got the Chicken Katsu, it was delicious.  The spicy is not too spicy, but enough to give it a nice kick.  The curry sauce give you a warm and happy feeling.  Good portions of rice, meat and curry.  The service is nice and polite which is appreciated. $8 for Pork or Chicken katsu curry.

Definitely give this place a try.  If you like Japanese Curry you will definitely want to come back.
author: Ty C.

description:
Wow! Let me start off by saying this place is worth the wait (the line is usually huge). I had the Katsu Curry Chicken and just thinking about it makes me want to go back there for more.

The spicy option isn't that spicy, so make sure to get it if you're in the market for something hot-ish.

Nom nom nom nom.
author: Yoni D.

description: There used to be a place called Andoh in Sunnyvale that made THE best Katsu Curry I've ever had. I think the owners family fell ill so he closed shop and went back to Japan. I've been searching for a suitable successor since. Now Japacurry wont replace Andoh in my book just yet, they still make a solid Katsu Curry, and they bring it to me! Bonus points. Croquette is also pretty tasty. It's great to see some traditionally authentic comfort food come to the masses in mobile form
author: Kim N.

description:
When you can't stop thinking about a food item and tell everyone on Earth about it within five minutes of finishing the dish, it's worth a five star rating. The dish I speak of is JapaCurry's Katsu Curry. Such a great newcomer on to the SF Street Food scene and with food like this, it's here to stay. 

First and foremost, Japanese staff!! Highly important and definitely imperative in the authenticity and deliciousness of the dish. Let's face it, the Japanese know Japanese curry. On to the eats... The quality of the pork was awesome and tasted clean and meaty, as it should. The crispy, panko crust was outta the world and was everything you hope for on a fried item. No excess grease, and done in the perfect shade of brown. The sauce carried a great balance to it and was definitely savored over the perfectly cooked rice grains (moist, short grain, but not too sticky). Chopped Japanese pickles complete the dish and bring it full circle with tartness and zing. 

 JapaCurry truck for a great lunch today @Civic Center Off the Grid. Props on your super cute truck too!!
author: Christina N.

description:
I'm a huge Japanese Curry snob and this truck
s curry is about a 2/5 at best. But when you consider the great price and the fact that Japanese Curry in this area is not so great you just have to add another star. 

I had the Kurobuta Sausage Curry and it was pretty good. The rice was right. The curry roux was flavorful but a little bit more watery than I would have liked - and with a tad too much seasoning (better than none I suppose).

Overall, I'll definitely come back.
author: Grayson K.

description:
I think it's 100% Japanese.
At least 2, because I spoke w/ them.

I finally got the Japo Curry.
Finally at Japantown! I was lucky. I have been looking for this truck.
What? It's not Japo? It's Japa? Oh, SORRY but it sounds same to me.

I have to say One thing.
The One thing is, This is GOOD SHIT!!!!
I got a Katsu Curry.
The Katsu was Nice Juicy inside, crispy out side, perfect.
The Curry was "muddy"in Good way, its not  too thick, has such a great flavor.

I grew up in Japan so I know what the Japo-Curry should taste like.
Don't get me wrong, I like Indian-Indian-Curry too.
But my mom did not think that what she was cooking was not Indian curry. She still thinking curry is curry. What she was cooking was "Japo-Curry".
Addition to that, there were curry shop almost every where in Japan. The curry shop was totally 100% Japo-style-curry, but the funny part was that people believed the curry is nothing different than Indian curry. 

Wrong!

So, I was very shocked when I had a Indian-Indian-Real-Curry. That was in San Francisco, when my boys were small, we had a Indian couple neighbor, invited us for dinner. It was very different. So different. I have to say it is curry but totally different dish. But I'd like say that there is a great Indian-Indian-Curry place on Valencia Street, is better than any Japo-style curry. That's for sure.

If there are 2 dish on a table, one Japo-Curry and the other, Indian-Indian-Curry. Which you pick?
I pick Indian-Indian-Curry w/ no doubt.
Japo-Curry isn't that deep as Real authentic Indian-Indian-Curry.

I like Japo-curry because I grew up with it.
Sentimental value.
But the value is pretty big in me.
I was eating the Japa-Curry's Katsu Curry like a pig in mud.
I was loving it.
Really Good Shit!
And I looked like a dirty Sanchaze.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Normally, I don't care for curry too much, but man. the katsu chicken curry was BOMB.

There's a delicate balance in making the perfect katsu chicken. I've been to places where their katsu had too much breading or wasn't crispy enough or that the meat was too dry. Japacurry's katsu chicken has these components spot on where the edges are crispy but not to the point where the breading scapes your mouth and the chicken is still juicy and tender.

The curry is given in a separate container to help you determine however much you want on the rice (though..i don't know why you wouldn't want to use it all up). One thing to note is that the spicy curry pretty much gives you a mild kick; it's not as spicy as you would expect.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Perfect crispy Pork Katsu with tender meat on the inside, over quality rice, and addicting curry sauce on the side! So yummy! I would buy a gallon of the curry alone to eat over rice at home.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Sorry, but it totally went down hill. 

Curry has no flavor. And man did they skimp on the curry. It's half of what they use to give you. 

I guess this is what happens when businesses get popular. Quality goes downhill. Don't think I will get JapaCurry again. =(
author: Mai H.

description:
The first thing I look for at a Japanese food place is a Japanese person. JapaCurry? check.

Their curry is pretty good. This (according to the name) is the main draw to this truck, and rightly so. It can be hard to find good Japanese curry anywhere, so track this truck down if you want your fix.

Pumpkin Croquette: pretty dang delish. I actually liked this the best. Creamy, slightly sweet, and fried to perfection. I could have put down about 3 of these suckers in one sitting.

I also had the black sesame tofu tiramisu. verdict: don't bother. It has a really strong tofu taste (and I love tofu)... but unless you like things like tofu cheesecake, tofu pie, or tofu ice cream (my grandma was on a tofu kick back in the early 90s so I have actually tried all of these things), you won't like this.


Would I return? Yup.
author: Jason A.

description:
I didn't feel like waiting in a long line for Muracci's, so I decided to get my curry fix from the Japacurry truck. 

I've gotten the kurobuta sausage curry and the potato and pumpkin croquette curry before, and they both were pretty good. They both came with some steamed veggies which was nice, so I didn't stuff my face with all the rice. 

A couple variations that were available were:

1. You can order the curry spicy for no extra charge. I can't eat spicy foods, but my coworker got her curry spicy, and she said it was delicious. 

2. You can get a side of cheese! This costs extra, but damn cheese and curry is my favorite! I typically use parmesan cheese at home when I eat curry, but the cheddar and jack cheese mix they give you here is still pretty darn good. The cheese mellows out the spice of the curry, so it's perfect for me. I know it sounds weird, but if you are a cheese lover like me, I would definitely recommend it! 

Another great food truck in sf!
author: Ayaka S.

description: Had the chicken curry. The chicken was tender and really tasty. One of the better curries I've had in SF. Simply made, and well done.
author: Zain M.

description: I usually get their chicken katsu curry. It's the best japanese food i ever had. It's so delicious. I usually have this food for lunch twice in a week. Good luck Japacurry!
author: Pandeeswaran B.

description: Really good.  Had the chicken katsu, karaage, and pork belly special.  High quality japanese curry from the owners of Izakaya Roku on Market Street
author: Jay H.

description:
Finally gave in to the temptation of JapaCurry Truck on a cold day in the city.  I ordered the chicken katsu curry over rice and it was delish.  It reminds me of my favorite curry dish that I used to get at this little spot in Japantown back when I was in law school.  Now, I can relive my curry-craving days just a block away from my office!  The katsu was perfectly breaded and crispy.  The rice was cooked just right.  When I got to my office, the curry had cooled off a little bit, which was unfortunate (and gave it a somewhat different consistency), but it was still good when I poured it over the katsu and rice and sprinkled on my favorite accompaniment -- pickled radish (?).  It wasn't the absolute best version of this dish I have ever had, but it came damn close.  Hell, it comes out of a truck and is made to travel!!
So good on a cold day and worth the weekday-after-lunch-food-coma.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
My coworkers love this place but me? Not so much. The food itself was rather bland (had the chicken). Also, few hours later, I got pretty bad indigestion, not food poisoning just felt really unwell soon after.

So no, probably not going back. No matter how awesome their truck smells when I'm on my way to lunch ANYWHERE ELSE.
author: Nicole P.

description:
I go here every Thursday when it's close to work.  I make sure to leave by 11:30 so that I can avoid the long line.

I always get chicken katsu with extra meat and extra curry.  Extra curry I'd recommend to anyone, the normal amount just isn't enough for all the meat and all the rice.  Extra meat is just for those of us that need to eat two peoples' worth of lunch to be full.

The quality isn't astoundingly good or anything, but it's reliable and tasty enough for a Thursday lunch.
author: Marty F.

description:
Standing in line for a salad bowl at Mixt Green..  when I checked in Foursquare, JapaCurry Truck popped up as one of the nearby spots.  A sudden craving for curry rice hit me and I had to go with my "gut" feeling. :)

The food truck didn't disappoint.  I got the deep fried pork cutlet with medium spicy curry.  Tonkatsu was definitely the best part! Thick cut.. juicy and tender nommm. I only wish that the curry sauce would have a smoother consistency and a sweeter taste (personal preference for Japanese curry). 

Bottomline: decent portion, reasonable price, and it warms you up on a cold SF summer day!
author: Michelle W.

description:
What a fantastic addition to the SOMA lunch scene.  A winsome orange truck that roams your neighborhood purveying your favorite food is the stuff of childhood daydreams.

In the obligatory comparison with Muracci's, the little kitchen on wheels wins my humble vote.  The plates are most notably cheaper by about $2, if only being slightly smaller.  If you're really packing an appetite, you'd best avoid the modestly apportioned kurobuta sausage.  The curry itself isn't as thick as Muracci's, but carries just as much flavor (if not more).

Check their website (http://www.japacurry.com) for their weekly schedule.  Mission & New Montgomery on Thursdays usually.
author: Alex C.

description:
This truck stops in front of the Blackrock building on Howard street every wednesday so come and get some of the best curry/fried chicken you will ever have.

I've gotten both the Katsu and the Kara-age and I would have to say that the kara-age is hands down the best fried chicken I have ever had. It's kind of like popcorn chicken that you get from boba places but so much more flavorful and the pieces are larger so the meat is a lot more tender and juicy (and you actually get meat instead of just breaded outside). The curry that you pour on top is pretty thick and really flavorful. You can customize the amount of spice they put in your curry and it goes great poured over the meat and rice. 

One serving is a lot of food so prepared to feel really stuffed afterwards. It is a little pricy at $8 per order but I think its a great comfort food when you are just looking for something simple and delicious.
author: Julie Z.

description: Their Tonkatsu Curry is sooooo good!!!!! Yes, this is a food truck, so you have to hunt them down and find a place to sit afterwards, but it's totally worth it! The tonkatsu is perfectly fried (not oily at all and not too crunchy to the point the it hurts your mouth afterwards) and the curry is just perfect! I usually don't like Japanese curry because it's way too salty for my taste, but this curry is the bomb! It's has the perfect balance of saltiness, sweetness, and spiciness. Eat all that with rice, PERFECT!
author: Michelle L.

description:
So continuing on with my food truck mission I try out Japacurry. Japanese curry is my comfort food and having been to Japan what feels like a million times, I have high expectations for my curry. 
Now first thing is first. The line here is always pretty long however it does move quickly so don't get intimidated. This truck is always sitting on Mission St between Second and New Montgomery on Thursdays so I stop by it since my office is not too far. I get the Chicken Katsu Curry Spicy. They give you a box with the rice and the chicken katsu and the curry in a separate container. I definitely appreciated the fact that the curry was in a separate container since it would not make the chicken katsu soggy. The portion is definitely satisfying and the $8 I paid for it seemed reasonable given the amount of food I had on my plate. The curry itself was OK. Not the best curry I have had for sure but it is very solid for being a food truck item. The curry itself is not very spicy to begin with which everyone seems to mention on yelp. Additionally the curry in my opinion is a bit watery compared to what I have had in Japan. Maybe it was just an "off day"? 
Nevertheless, definitely a joint I would not mind eating at again but I am not sure that I would purposely seek this place out.
author: Dan M.

description: Katsu Kare hits the spot....really good. For $7 it's one of the better valued food trucks that I've tried. Their curry is good. The negative however, is if you want it spicy, they just sprinkle a little togarashi on it.
author: Craig I.

description:
J ust simply my favorite Japanese curry within the city
A nd it's crazy that it's from a food truck!
P erfect treat for lunch, perfectly flavored for my taste buds
A s I chow down the last piece of curry-coated Kurobuta sausage, all I can think is:
C an I just get one more bite?
U m, maybe two?
R ecommend coming for the chicken katsu and Kurobota sausage curries
R ecommend coming early to pick up a bento box before they sell out
Y ou won't be disappointed
author: Anthony N.

description:
I'm a fan of Japanese curry for reasons I don't fully understand.  Its not like its "real" curry - its basically Japanese fast food.  But no matter how much you enjoy fine food, you can still make room for a greasy cheeseburger if its really, really good, right?  That's how I feel about Japanese curry, and JapaCurry is really, really good.

I got the Kara Age curry the first time I went, and its so good I haven't tried anything else yet.  Basically, boneless chunks of fried chicken, lightly battered and not greasy, with curry sauce and rice.  Yum.  

I see a lot of people comparing JapaCurry to Muracci's, but I think there is no comparison.  JapaCurry is far better.  They are at Sansome and Pine on Fridays, so I really hope the FiDi turns out for them so they keep coming back.
author: Michael D.

description:
Cash only!

I've been getting the Katsu Curry. It feels like too much curry, but when you get down to the last few bites, you wish you had just a little bit more.
author: Chris V.

description: They're curry sauce is nectar of the gods. I want to pour it over everything.
author: Christian C.

description:
The bright orange food truck caught my eye yesterday when I was on my way to Sushirrito.. I knew I had to see what this was all about! I hunted down the food truck today and ordered their Chicken Katsu curry. Their special bento box was sold out today (around 12:20, they start at 11). The wait wasn't long at all (althought I think I may have gotten sunburnt while waiting under the sun.. but that's just me). I don't usually eat curry, especially Japanese curry, so I wasn't sure what to expect.

The chicken katsu was so crunchy and tender, but the skin wasn't burnt. There was the perfect ratio of curry to rice and my tummy couldn't have felt more satisfied. There was a hint of spice in the curry but it was not overwhelming at all. 

I'M COMING BACK FOR YOU JAPACURRY!!!

They're cash only, but you can pay through a mobile app called level up, where you can use a debit/credit card to pay. Apparently you can get rewards on this app too, so I'm going to use it next time I order at Japacurry!
author: Jeannie W.

description:
Was lucky enough to try this place out at Off the Grid: Fort Mason. 

Went with the Tonkatsu Curry over rice. Loved the depth of flavor coming from the sauce. I was expecting mainly a sweet taste, since that seems to be a characteristic of Japanese curry, but I was surprised that there was a nice kick of spiciness as well. The pork itself is alright. Not super tender, which would've been ideal but a good balance with the curry. 

I'm not sure if I'd put this place over Muraccis, since you can choose the level of spiciness there. Nevertheless, JapaCurry is a solid choice and I'd be happy to go again.

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
This place never fails me. 

Ordered chicken curry Katsu  with double spiciness level. Simple yet satisfying. Curry combines onion and curry for a delicate balance sweet and flavorful. 

No line today. I do recommend going before/after 12. 

Simply said simplicity at its finest. Offering Asian comfort food for $8.
author: Christopher S.

description:
I'm confused as to why this place is getting such high reviews. I know it's on a truck, but that doesn't excuse JapaCurry for having less-than-mediocre curry. I ordered the pork cutlet curry. It was quite disappointing.
