The sauce had a bit too much cumin and was more on the sweet side than what I would prefer. No veggies when I know for a fact the Japanese put in at least carrots in their curry. What bothered me the most was that the curry wasn't even spicy at all! I had to eat it with kimchi borrowed from the kalbi taco truck parked a few feet away. The pork cutlet was dry and flavorless--not happy!! I also didn't like the fact that the pickled radish wasn't contained separately from the rice and curry. It got lost at the bottom of my rice and stained it with a hot pink, reddish hue. By the time I found it, I wasn't able to enjoy it with my curry because I had already gotten full.

Okay, I get that being served from a truck doesn't allow for A+ presentation, and I do give JapaCurry 1 star for attracting me with their decked out cutesy truck and branding. However, there is absolutely no reason why the basic curry sauce should be compromised.

Sorry, Mr. Hamada and JapaCurry fans. I no like.
author: Trinity G.

description: Ordered the curry sandwich. 4 dollars for bread covered in panko. Had to bite all the way to the middle to get a taste of curry. Everything else was just deep fried panko. So not worth it. Co worker ordered katsu curry spicy. Food was bland not spicy at all. Sorry Japa Curry, I will not be coming back.
author: Allen L.

description:
Slightly better, closer (to my work), and faster than Murraci's.

However, they need to kick up the heat on their "spicy" curry because its not spicy at all. I wouldn't even call it medium...more like a mild.

I usually get their pork katsu curry. The food comes out nice and hot since it was probably just cooked and has a very crisp panko bread crumb coating.

If you're feeling extra hungry, add in a side of the potato/pumpkin croquette.
author: Lester W.

description: Their katsu curry is really good. Their curry is tasty and have a thick consistency. The  pork katsu meat  and rice is well made. The quality of their food is very consistent. The kurobuto sausage curry is also pretty good.  They use twitter to post their current location, since they tend to move around a lot. Friendly service good value. You can use your iPhone to pay (via Level Up). Their spicy flavor curry is not as spicy as other curry places like Kare-Ten.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
JapaCurry is new favorite food truck. For lunch I had the pork katsu curry over rice. The curry was addictively delicious--better than Muracci's and even better than Curry House in Hawaii (which I grew up on and looove). The pork cutlet was perfectly breaded and fried to a golden brown. I could really eat this once a week.

My only grievance is that there's far too little curry for the volume of rice. And I want more fukujinzuke. How am I going to cut the savoriness of the curry with just a few slivers of pickle?

Apparently JapaCurry will be a introducing a katsu curry burrito soon. Very excited. I can't wait for my next lunch break here.
author: Liz T.

description: I heard that they tried to copy Muracci's curry. I think this is right  as both are similar and NOT Japanese curry. But I still like Japacurry better than Muracci's. The owner tried to sell curry as Muracci's sells well. But my question is that the owner really think his curry is traditional Japanese curry. Unfortunately, no. But I really want them to be successful!
author: Maki N.

description:
Once upon a  time, not long ago, food trucks were all called roach coaches. Some are good, this one's a rope.
Trendy things are not always good things. Remember that. 

JapaCurry really sucks.  Why? Curry isn't much to write home about, there's way more rice than veggies and if you want meat, go see another truck because you won't get much from this one... For a $10 or $11 lunch and an annoying line, it shouldn't suck.  

Repeating in case you didn't read: 'Trendy things are not always good things. Remember that.'

The 1 star is for the pumpkin croquette.  Hear that pumpkin?
author: Athena S.

description: O.M.G.  This place is amazeballs! I finally had just enough cash for JapaCurry and it seriously made my day!  i would go as far as to say this is the best lunch I've had in the area since April when I started work in the area!  I had the pumpkin croquette curry and got it spicy...so good. can't wait to try out the rest of the menu
author: Annette E.

description: JapaCurry serves about four basic curry dishes and about four basic bento boxes (and sides and sodas). The selection doesn't offer a large range of options, but it's probably as much as a food truck can offer. The food is alright -- fairly authentic, in both presentation and taste (It reminded me of the food I've had in Japan). I didn't find it particularly amazing, but for what it is -- a food truck offering foreign food -- it's pretty good.
author: Luke K.

description: Love their katsu chicken curry with cheese! Get there early though (before noon if you can) because they run out of things quick (at least whenever they're on Mission and New Montgomery).
author: Tiffany F.

description:
i think their katsu curry is whatevs, but i think their chicken karage curry is fannnntastic! it's perfectly seasoned and the right amount of crunch. 

i do think they need to make their curries spicier...dont be shy mr.japacurry, i can take it! the last time i was here, i saw that when i asked for spicy, they scribbled down Xs. in my mind a XXX in spice is suppose to have me breaking out a sweat, but i barely drank any water as a inhaled my lunch.

anyway, this place is good. remember to bring cash, since it's CASH ONLY :(
author: Andy H.

description: Got the curry tofu over rice. The tofu was pretty solid, it was nice and crispy, but there wasn't enough of it with too much rice. The curry wasn't flavorful or spicy (which I asked for)
author: Amaresh S.

description:
I love a gourmet food truck parked one block from my work...  One day, it was JapaCurry.  The only veggie option (tofu bento box was sold out) was a pumpkin/potato croquette with curry.  Sold.

The meal was aesthetically pleasing and really f**ing tasty.  The croquette was crispy outside gooey inside and I did not want to sully it with curry, except the curry sauce was really good and I ended up smothering everything in it and eating every last bite and it was oh.so.good.

I spent a few hours pleasantly surprised at how lightly my gluttony sat, but it did hit me after that.  And it was all worth it.  When are they back again?
author: Andi T.

description:
I don't know what this stupid Off the Grid thing at Ft. Mason is or what people who live in SF know about living places where there isn't a grid, but I won't hold that against the tasty curry I just had.

In addition to the curry, I admire the fact that they aren't wrapping the curry in burritos or some half-ass fusion thing like that.  This is good honest comfort food, quick and reasonably priced for the area.
author: Jared L.

description:
After having a very disappointing culinary experience at the Seoul on Wheels truck ( we were @ Off the Grid) - we wandered over to JapaCurry. I've been wanting to try this truck for a long time too and I must say I was a little worried. Was I going to be disappointed here too? 

OK here goes nothing as we put in our order for the pork katsu curry...well, not nothing - it cost us six bucks...ha ha 

Wondering if we will be returning to this truck aren't ya? Hell yeah we will be! The curry was really good. We asked for it spicy and there was this red powder on top and once mixed in - it gave it a nice heat. The katsu was a decent size and hearty. We finished the bowl and drained the curry down to practically nothing. 

Japa we will be back! You made me a fan!
author: Cris H.

description:
YUMMY!!! This truck has totally changed my opinion on Japanese Curry! I used to avoid it much like the plague at Japanese restaurants and never understood why so many people loved it so much. Yucky looking funky flavor sauce over fried chicken... but this stuff is good!

Thanks to JapaCurry truck parked across the street from my work.. I am a true curry fan now!

Try it at least once! There are long lines for a reason.

 Mission and New Montgomery from 11:15-1:45pm
author: Mia N.

description:
Last week, my friend and I foolishly went to the truck at 12:45pm and were sad to discover that there was no more curry.  This week, we learned from our mistake and went to the truck at 11:45am.  We had to wait about 20 mins. to place our order, but it was definitely worth it.

My friend and I split the chicken katsu and pumpkin and potato croquette curry.  We were both pleasantly surprised that we were still full 6 hours later since the portion sizes didn't look that substantial.  We both inhaled our food and I don't even like rice!  The chicken katsu and pumkin and potato croquette were both perfectly breaded and fried.  I also tried the pork katsu and found that the chicken was more tender. The pumpkin and potato croquette was absolutely lovely.  The curry was very well flavored though the spicy isn't very spicy (and I don't have a particularly high tolerance for spicy foods so I was a little surprised).  I would agree with other yelpers that the curry tastes better than Muracci, which means it is pretty good. 

You can get brown rice for an additional 50 cents.  They keep the curry in a container separate from the rice, which is good if you are walking far away or eating it later, but bad if you care about the environment.

There is also a stamp card where you get a free curry with every 12th purchase.
author: Amy C.

description:
I do love JapaCurry. The spicy curry sauce, the pickled daikon.. Mmm. And it works for them, because IMO those are two elements that can truly make a good katsu curry.

I know, I know.. Muracci's is the traditional go-to place for katsu curry in SF. But, to be honest, something about the curry sauce at JapaCurry hits the spot for me. I've had many a craving for JapaCurry, and usually, Muracci's is my back-up plan - though a great one as well that deserves all of it's 3.5 Yelp stars.

Since late spring of 2011, I've probably eaten here about 6-8 more times than my (currently) 3 check-ins suggest.


:::: THE FOOD ::::

* PUMPKIN CROQUETTE
            - [4.5/5 - LOVE this. I've always been a big fan of croquettes, though. I have friends who find the mushy texture off-putting, but that's what makes it such great comfort food, imo.]
* CURRY SAUCE
            - [4/5 - It's actually spicy! I do add a few drops of Tabasco in mine, too. Then again, I always carry a bottle in my purse. I did have to subtract 1/2 a star for the lack of thickness in the sauce. It's a bit more watery than I prefer, but at least they make up for it in flavor.]
* PICKLES
            - [4.5/5 - My biggest qualm is only that they give you so little of this! I always need extra pickles because each perfect bite must consist of some to balance out the curry.]
* PORK KATSU
            - [3.5/5 - I mean, it's fried & breaded pork cutlets. Not really something I'd ever look for or crave without the accompaniments. Plus, if you aren't eating it right away, it can expectedly get a bit chewy.]
* CHICKEN KATSU
            - [3.5/5 - Once again, fried & breaded chicken cutlets.]

After trying a couple of different combinations, my order has stayed consistent the last 3 times I went:
* 1/2 PORK & 1/2 CHICKEN KATSU CURRY (possible when with company)
* EXTRA PICKLES
* 1/2 EXTRA CURRY SAUCE (possible when with company)
* 1 PUMPKIN CROQUETTE.
... This usually does last me across two meals (or 1.5 meals) if I'm eating alone, or 1 meal if I'm sharing with another.
author: Asha S.

description:
Food Truck craze lives on in SF...although not like NYC

Had the Katsu Curry and a Pumpkin Croquette today.  Very tasty.  

The line wasn't too long, and the JapaCurry folks are very nice.

Their website lets you know where they will be.  You have 2:15 hours to grab your grub (11:30-1:45)

The next two times, I'm gonna try their Tofu Bento, and their K. Sausage Curry...
author: Derek N.

description:
Better than Muracci's! 

Why?
1. Sauce is just as flavorful as Muracci's but thicker (which I prefer)
2. Cheaper ($8 for the katsu chicken or pork)
3. Faster (Waited 5-10 minutes only @ 11:35 am on a Wednesday)
4. Closer to work (usually parked on Mission & New Montgomery)
5. The red pickled thing tastes better than Muracci's pickled vege

Only down side? The portions are small. It's not really a downside for me because I thought it was a perfect portion. But if you have the appetite of a growing boy, it might leave you wanting more since the portion is a bit smaller than what you can find at Muracci's.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I tried this truck when they came to Sactomofo a couple of weeks ago and it was sooo good! For $7, I got a katsu curry with some rice and it was filling. I even shared it with a guy and you know how men eat. LOL jk. The katsu was crispy and the curry was at a good mild spice. It wasn't overwhelming at all. 

There's not much else to say cause this place is bomb!
author: Linda N.

description:
Simplicity at its finest.  They didn't do anything to transform the dish into some kind of fusion cuisine.  They didn't add different vegetables or different spices.  They simply made curry.

Quite possibly the best curry I have ever had in the City. Yes, Murraci's is very good but I personally think JapaCurry is better. Given the fact that it's from a food truck and that you have to eat on the street, I thought it was fantastic. Both the chicken and pork katsu were breaded lightly, it was crispy, golden in color, and were juicy. The star of the dish was the curry.   

I usually do not finish the rice. After I finished my chicken katsu and nibbled from Sandy L.'s pork katsu, I had some rice left. I poured the rest of the curry in my rice and finished the rest of the curry. It was fork licking good. There is absolutely nothing I would change about this curry. 

Check it out!!!! They are the real deal.
author: jason g.

description:
Love, love, love the pork katsu curry! Oh and try the croquettes, too! Seriously, I would eat this every day if I could get away with not getting fat. Yes, there's usually a line but it moves quickly. I've searched high and low for other curry places to find the same flavor profile but nothing compares. 

Quick tips:
- if you're ordering a bento box, they are pre-made and you can just get them from the back window instead of waiting in line
- if you're a frequent eater (like me), get a frequent eater card and don't forget to get it stamped
author: Novi M.

description: If you don't have Japanese curry close by this will do in a pinch. Come early though as the lines get long and there is also a limit to the number of entrees you can get so you may need to bring a buddy for group office lunch runs. Personally I like the curry at volcano or muraccis better.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Man, who knew that Japanese curry from a truck would be so delicious? I usually see the JapaCurry truck near Mission and 2nd, but due to the drama with Harvest and Rowe, they were offered a guest parking spot from the Rib Whip dudes over on Ritch Street. 

I ordered the chicken katsu curry, which was REALLY good. However, I thought that for $8, they should put a little more meat, and a little less white rice.

Be careful when you eat this, because after eating that much rice during lunch, I knocked out for 2.5 hours. Good thing I'm a student and had a break from class, otherwise I'd have that uneasy feeling where you drift off, and you think everyone saw it.

Overall, it was delicious and under 10 bucks. I was reasonably full (but I still wish there was more chicken).
author: Louis N.

description:
The JapaCurry truck graces us with its presence every Tuesday and Wednesday on 1st & Howard. 

I don't often like to order Japanese curry because I can easily make it at home, but I heard about this food truck, did some research and decided to give it a try. 

This is my 2nd visit and both times i have ordered the Pork Katsu Curry dish. 

The curry has a nice consistency to it. Personally I'd like it to be slightly thicker but thats just a texture preference for me. The flavor is really great. It just has this succulent Japanese curry flavor that is wholesome but not overpowering. I just wish they would give more per order so I dont have to worry about rationing my curry to have sauce for every bite. =( 

The Katsu has always been cooked perfectly. It's nice and crispy and not too oily and the pork has a nice juiciness to it on the bite. Good flavor and I appreciate the little drizzle of katsu sauce to top it off. 

Tons of rice. YEY. Brown rice option available for the more health conscious folks.

The 2nd time around I ordered veggies with my curry. The chunks were a bit huge but def worth the money. They were tender but not soggy. Definite plus. 

I also ordered the Kurobuta sausage on the side with my 2nd trip. Tastes kind of like a hotdog. Juicy, but hotdog. Don't think I'll be ordering that again out of personal pref. Katsu is more worth it to me. 

Service is always polite and pretty speedy! 

Extra Note: You can scan your clipper card as a loyalty card thing. I got 1.00 off my order today =)

Be prepared to pay for anything you ask for extra, even the red pickles =(
author: Beck P.

description:
I'd been dying to try this truck so when it stopped near my husband's work for lunch, he was kind enough to bring some home for me to dinner.

The kurobuta sausage curry was delicious. I've always been a fan of those little sausages and the combination of that with the homemade curry was delicious. For those of you who have never tried Japanese curry, this is a great place to start. As good as the Japanese curry is out of the box, this is 100x better because you can taste all the vegetables and seasonings that give the curry a wonderfully layered taste.

We will definitely seek this truck out again soon!
author: Cindy N.

description:
Absolutely my favorite food truck.

For $8 you can get a delicious katsu curry with rice and a side of pickled vegetables that is sure to fill you up. The meat is always perfectly crispy even if not eaten immediately as you run to eat it elsewhere. The curry sauce is fragrantly spiced but not in a hot way, in a full of spices way.

Even when lines are longer, food is fast and piping hot. Awesome job.
author: Sam H.

description:
3.5 stars for Japacurry Truck. 

Tired of eating at the same establishments day in and day out around the Financial District during lunch hour? I sure as heck am. Food trucks have been the only redeeming aspect of lunching in this area lately. 

I had the BBQ beef bento box today. All of the curries were sold out very quickly after I came back to the truck from the ATM. So I'll have to update my review for the actual curry to be fair, it is called the Japacurry truck after all.

After a fairly painless wait, I got my bento for $8. A bit expensive for a pre-cooked lunch, but I'm so sick of eating elsewhere that I didn't care. As for the food, the beef was very tasty. It came on a bed of caramelized onions 
and lots of rice. I wish there were more veggies, but oh well. It was satisfying for what it was. 

Overall it was kind of an acceptable...meal. I had high expectations after reading all the rave reviews on here, but don't get your hopes too high, at least for the bento boxes. Tips? Bring cash. Come early.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
Great truck to hunt down. I really like their Katsu Chicken (spicy) with brown rice. I would always walk by the truck on the way to the Ferry Building, but one day I decided to give it a try. The line was about 7-deep, but went quickly and the order came of fast, too. Even when I ate leftovers the next day, it was tasty. 

I recommend. Plus, when they're parked on Howard & 1st, Kara's Cupcakes parks next to them (oh Kara!). Anyway, they've made my work-lunch rotation.
author: Trinity M.

description:
I tried Japacurry's Croquette Curry a few months ago. I thought it was good, but I like Muracci's curry a lot more.

They gave me one squash croquette over a lot of rice and some cabbage. I appreciated the cabbage. But just one croquette? I was sad. Imagine a panda being served one stick of bamboo. I really like croquettes and it was good, but I expected it to either be bigger or there'd be two of them.

They use compostable containers (yay) but the rice sticks to it (boo). The curry sauce it tasty but kind of thin, and not as complex as other Japanese curries I've had.

Wait time was short for such a long line. They burn through the line pretty fast and I think the food is all ready in the truck so they just need to plate it up and serve you.  This truck is still a bit of a walk for me, so I'll opt for phoning in to pick up Muracci's instead. If you go make sure to get the frequent buyer card.
author: Amy N.

description:
Complete ripoff.  For $9.50 I got brown rice, flavorless breaded fried chicken, a cup of curry that tasted like peppered gravy thickened with a lot of cornstarch, and count 'em -- 3 -- yes, 3 -- measly pieces of warmed-up frozen vegetables.  Oh, and 2 sick looking slices of potato, and a teeny tiny plastic cup of pickled vegetable slivers.  

I've made curry from a box with tons of fresh vegetables and better quality chicken to feed 8 people, for just about the same amount of money.  My curiousity as to what all the hype about was sorely disappointed here.
author: Sue Z.

description:
The line is long but it moves quickly. They're very nice people.
The most important thing though, is that their chicken katsu is fried perfectly, crisp and not greasy in the least. Is frying a pounded chicken cutlet hard? why is it that everyone who does not work at the japacurry truck turn chicken katsu into a nauseatingly oily abomination? maybe in such a small space they pay closer attention, or the limited menu means there's less prep or other tasks to distract them. I don't know.

I also don't know about the ratio of rice and curry sauce (incidentally the spicy curry sauce is only mildly spicy) to chicken, but if you have some other dish back at the office that could really use a little rice or curry then you're all set.

But yeah, a dish from a truck that actually tastes better than the same dish from most sit down restaurants. San Francisco is a crazy place.
author: matthew r.

description:
I didn't even know that this truck existed until I read the drama between Japacurry and Harvest and Rowe on SFoodie. Out of sheer curiosity, me and my coworkers went ahead and trekked the 7 block walk from my work to SoMa. Got there around 1145 and there were 20 or so people ahead of us. I soon find out that they are very efficient as it took about 15 minutes to get to the front and not even 5 minutes to get our food.
The curry is so flavorful and hearty, the fried chicken katsu was crispy, they made sure to not close the lid so it wouldn't get soggy. I'm sure if they parked their truck any closer to my neck of the woods they would definitely give Muracci's a run for their money.

UPDATE: They are now parked at Sansome and Pine once a week!
author: Rachelle Q.

description: Tried the Japacurry truck last week for the first time.  The spicy Chicken Katsu Curry and Kurobuta sausage were excellent.  Generous portions for lunch.  Line was fairly long, but it moved quickly and the staff were very friendly.  Authentic Japanese curry.  I'll be going back.
author: Lon H.

description: I love Japanese Curry! If you love japanese curry too you will like this truck. At first I was a little worried about purchasing curry from a food truck, but they package it really well. Both the chicken and the pork in the katsu curry were nice and tender. mmm! Thinking about this truck just makes me hungry again. i can eat katsu curry every day! There's not much in the package besides a few pieces of katsu, rice, and curry though. (That doesn't bother me at all) but if you're one to love veggies, this may not be the order for you. Their bento boxes looked good too... one day I'll try one of those! :)
author: Annie Z.

description: Friendly service, yummy curry! I can't decide if I like this one or Muracci's better (I had the pork katsu).  If you get there early, you avoid the long lines at noon.  They move very quickly --always a plus in my book.  Can't wait to try their sausage curry next!
author: Anne S.

description:
I do love Japanese curry and while I think this truck does it well, I wasn't that impressed with the Pumpkin and Potato Croquette Curry. I LOVE their Pumpkin croquette on its own, I think it's fantastic and would happily just order it alone.

The serving was kind of big for me, which is fine but basically it's steamed veggies with a pumpkin croquette and some slices of potato. The curry is separate which you can add in but there's something odd about just pouring curry over steamed veggies rather than having them in the curry in the first place. Maybe I'm just particularly picky since I tend to eat at another Japanese curry joint almost every week and I'm used to the veggies being in the curry. Call me weird, but the veggies tend to seep in the flavour and will just taste better rather than having distinct tastes stand apart.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Following Jay Hamada (owner and chef) and his phenomenal Japacurry family is  definitely worth it. 

From 'Off the Grid' and yonder Jay parks his his well-sheened orange gourmet food truck serving up some of the best curry Japan has to offerin the US.

Of course I've had the house fave..Pork Katsu!! (numerous times now) The sauce has a deep rich flavor more than any curry I've had in the past. Crispy light battered filet of pork ,steamed rice and red ginger pickles all complement the dish.

Look forward to my next feast...
author: Dave S.

description:
Katsu curry pork cutlet with spicy curry over some rice = $8
Oi Oshi ocha = $2
Happy Tummy afterwards = priceless

After chasing them to find a long line everytime they were in the FiDi, i caught em in the SOMA area. (yes!) ordered right up, came out in 3 mins (no lie) and i commenced shoveling food within the next 2 mins (true story!). Now, I am a Japanese curry aficionado (used to eat it all the time in Osaka) and there are few places where i get my fix (not gonna say so i can continue to get reasonable service) but this is one place or i mean truck, to add to the books. i love the savory, spicy sauce with the all the various spices and the onions so boiled down they're like strings or dental floss already. the cutlet was nicely fried and the rice was decent enough to finish every bite as a chaser. good thing i got more sauce than i needed so i could take it home and use it on some more rice and home-cooked katsu for round 2 (boo-yah!) Onaka Ippai!
author: Nick V.

description: Waited in a long line at Sacto Mofo to eat my chicken katsu curry plate, but it was worth it. I got the mango custard dessert and it went very well with the spicy curry. Reminded me of my Grandma's homecookin' - definitely check them out if they're in your 'hood.
author: Drew T.

description:
This place has really good japanese curry and there's generally a much smaller line than the nearby Curry-Up truck.  I've had both the chicken katsu and the pork katsu curry dishes.  The curry was good and similar to the level of Muracci's.  But I'd say Muracci's wins in a close race.  Order the spicy curry.  Keep in mind, 'spicy' in Japanese food is like the level of heat in a taco bell sauce packet - i.e. not at all spicy.  

The meals are $8 and therefore "cheaper" than Muracci's.  But at Muracci's, the katsu is bigger/thicker, you can get brown rice for free (JapaCurry charges $0.50), and they give more rice.  So JapaCurry is giving the same value per $ as Muracci's.  Basically, you'll pay almost $2 more, but get 25% more food at Muracci's.  The plus here is that it's much quicker.  

Don't forget to Badgein with your Clipper card for savings.

Pro tip:  Rather than ordering the Kurobata sausage curry and complaining about the size, order a Katsu curry and pay an extra $0.75 per sausage.  It's a 10x better deal.
author: Jon K.

description:
Another one of my favorite food trucks in the city! I'm here about once a week.

Consistently good food and portions. The food is prepared pretty quickly, although the line can be insanely long at lunch. If you show up later they are sure to run out of what you want.

I usually get the chicken katsu curry. The sausages are kinda dinky. -.5

The prices are alright I guess. I mean, for a meal it's like $8. But if you want to make it spicy, they charge you for like 1/16th teaspoon of cayenne pepper or something. C'mon! -.5
author: Harold C.

description:
The truck is always on time on Thursdays, Mission and New Montgomery. I can see it parked outside of my window.  First time trying japacurry and I ordered the Pork Katsu with brown rice, pumpkin croquette and sausage.  Pretty much everything on the menu.  They also have special plates, but since it was my first time, I wanted to stick with the originals first.  An additional .50 cents for brown rice and a dollar to add the pumpkin croquette came out to be about $11?!

The curry was delicious, but it wasn't anything special that I haven't tried before. OVERRATED
author: Chanel L.

description:
Never thought delicious curry could be served out of a food truck. Japa curry is that truck.

They serve some of the most simple yet delicious curry plates in the city. I got the Katsura curry and the cut of meat was generous and fried to perfection. They also gave a generous amount of curry sauce which i drowned my rice and meat in. Simply delicious!

Their curry definitely rivals that of muracci's.
author: David W.

description:
The curry is just ok. Nothing special to be honest. I've tried a few dishes and the meat is just bland. While their curry is ok it's no superstar. Decent food for a decent price but I wouldn't go out of my way for the truck. It's usually within 2 block of my office downtown so I get them when nothing else seems like a good idea for lunch.
Cash only but they do accept LevelUp payments
author: Paul B.

description:
Yummy, spicy Japanese comfort food. Perfect for chilly days! The box comes with white rice, steamed veggies, and meat/croquettes, and the curry comes in a little container on the side. 

I thought the veggies were a little bland (and the onion was definitely underdone) and the rice was a little overcooked, but that's just being nitpicky. Cheaper than Muracci's and just as tasty. I'll be back!

I'd suggest coming before 12 to beat the inevitable massive line.
author: Lisa W.

description:
This is good stuff! Some Japanese curry tastes like they simply took a block of the stuff and warmed it up. Not JapaCurry. This is excellent curry. It has the subtle flavors that are missing from most of what you will find around the Bay.

I've had the sausage, chicken katsu, and pork katsu. Everything was delicious, and I will have them all again.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
I gave this truck a try last Friday in front of City Hall.

If you want a pork katsu that is perfectly breaded, tender, juicy, and very slightly crisped, look no further!  The amount of rice that comes with the order is definitely enough to fill you up for lunch.  I also like the the little cup of red pickled vegetables that they give you with the order.  The wait line may look long, but they are quick to deliver your food.  $8 isn't super cheap for what you get, but I don't mind paying due to the good quality of the food!  If you are thirsty, you can get a soda for $1.
author: Pat S.

description:
You need to eat lunch. Much more importantly, Japan needs help. Both can be accomplished at the same time this week. JapaCurry is donating 10% of proceeds to relief efforts. Trust me, the veggie curry (bell pepper, zucchini and carrots over rice) tastes better knowing you are helping a very good cause. This is not the week to debate whether the veggie/rice balance is right. It doesn't matter. You are eating for a greater cause.

And tip well. Japan and your karma need it.
author: Jason B.

description:
Met my friend for lunch one day and she suggested this food truck.  Food truck???  Would it be good?  I've had burritos from a food truck, but that's been it.  

I didn't realize what a big phenomenon food trucks had become until recently.  I had the chicken katsu curry.  Surprisingly, it was really, really good!  Very good portion of chicken and white rice.  Sauce on the side, so your food doesn't get soggy while you find a place to eat.

So, my love of the food truck began with this simple lunch.  Yay!
author: Denise M.

description:
I'm so glad we have JapaCurry Truck to add to our lunch menu. I really enjoyed their Chicken Katsu. 

Like a majority of everyone else on here, I thought their chicken was well breaded and crispy. The curry was really what will keep me coming back to JapaCurry. I could tell it was homemade because it was fresh, I saw chunks of onions in there. The level of spiciness was just perfect. I poured the entire container over my chicken katsu and white rice. I pretty much devoured my lunch that day.

I love the orange truck and I love how it's moderately priced at $8, still under the average SF lunch. 

See you next week, Japa!
author: Cindy W.

description: Japacurry hangs out near my office and I've picked up lunch there a few times. There's always a decent size line but it moves quickly.  I think you can avoid the line if you want to order something other than curry but that would be a bad move.  Go for the tried and true - chicken katsu curry. Warm, rich, filling, savory, and delightful. Avoid wasting $ on the squash croquets - they're good but not enough to worry over.
author: Ivan L.

description:
I'm a huge fan.  I am also quite addicted.  I don't know what they put in it, maybe the spice? but over rice, the curry is absolute perfection.

Their fried pork and chicken also smells very delicious and mouth watering.  I think couplel months ago I went back to back Fridays.  I think I can have it twice a week and not get tired of it.  
Def. hit up this truck if you see it in your neighborhood!
author: AhLin C.

description:
I will start by saying that i don't love curry.  But I thought I would give it a try since they made a visit to my office.  

I figured I love chicken katsu, so I would give it a whirl.  They give you the curry sauce on the side if like me you are leery.

I also got a pumpkin/potato croquette.

The portions were generous, and that curry was GOOD.  good flavor and the rice was well made.  Both the chicken katsu and the croquette were cooked perfectly.  

I actually had a bit of rice left over, but it was really tasty, and i would definitely go back.
author: Lu E.

description:
The distinguished-looking JapaCurry truck was parked across the street from work, so I had to check it out.  Normally, I don't like curry, but KATSU CURRY seemed very appealing.  

There was no disppointment whatsoever!  This place is ridiculously good!  I know the focus of the truck is curry, which is very good by the way.  However, the overshadowed understudy has to be the TONKATSU.  The crispy tonkatsu skin was perfectly light and tasty.  It was better than any tonkatsu I've ever had.  These guys are serious Tonkatsuologists.

The best part was that they put the curry in a container.  I was dipping each piece of tonkatsu HALF WAY into the curry, so I could enjoy both Curry Katsu and the Naked Katsu in its own ALL-NATURALE splendor.  The best of both worlds!  I also had enough curry leftover to take home.  I found myself trying to find anything edible to dip into the curry.

The freight on the wonderful meal was $8!   Awesome price for SOMA, especially when the other choices in the area could be $10-$12 at Sushi "not so" Fantastic.

JapaCurry has transformed Tuesdays on Howard Street into the best workday of the week.  (they were even the featured photo in a WSJ article about food carts in SF).
author: Sequoia S.

description:
What I ordered: Pork Katsu Curry & Pumpkin Croquette

The Good: Pork Katsu, pumpkin croquette, tiny pickle side, and curry sauce were all yummy. Lots of ways to build your order a la carte.

The Bad: Pricey if you want a full meal since a la carte items will take you over $10. Base dish doesn't have much to it, just meat and tons of rice, plus a REALLY SMALL side of red pickle (extra is less than $1, but these add up). 

I've eaten a lot of Japanese food and a lot of curry, but this was my first time eating Japanese curry. I'm definitely down for more! This is an excellent to-go option as the curry sauce (which you can order spicy) comes in a separate container and doesn't get your meat & rice all soggy.

The pork katsu was pretty much spot on and dipping it in the tub of curry sauce just took it over the top. I will definitely try this truck again, if I'm not looking for a cheap lunch, but it will be hard not to go back to the pork katsu.

I like lots of rice, so I didn't have problem with the large quantity of white rice. They gave me extra curry sauce (I suspect because I ordered the croquette too) which I just dumped all over the rice after I was done with the other items. The red pickle made a good condiment for the rice, in spite of how little was provided.

The pumpkin croquette was very good, but as it is also offered as the veggie meal option, I'm not sure that one or two of those would really make a good meal for someone wanting to skip the meat (as I sometimes do).  There are vegetable and cheese options as sides, which I did not try, so this is definitely not the final word on whether a fully vegetarian meal could be achieved here.

All in all, my first visit to JapaCurry was positive. The food was a solid GOOD, I'll need to sample the full menu before I can say it's any better than that.
author: R. S.

description:
Good and solid curry. 
Perfectly cooked rice.
author: JK C.

description:
I LOVE THIS FOOD TRUCK.

I'm so glad they come to Sansome and Pine on Tuesdays.  For $7 you can get chicken or pork katsu with a ton of rice and a ton of curry.  That's cheaper than Muracci's!  And -- dare I say it -- it tastes better than Muracci's!  

And come on...how fun is it to order from a food truck?

I am definitely eating this every Tuesday from now on.

Also, earlier this week they were donating 10% of their profit to Japan.  A little help goes a long way :)
author: Alyssa S.

description:
Yum! This is Japanese curry at its best considering the mobile nature of this enterprise. 

Foodie notes: I had the chicken katsu and the crisp was perfect, the meat was tender and the curry sauce came on the side so everything stayed fresh. 

One downside--the curry containers are these plastic non-recyclable things. I wish they'd use something a bit more enviro-friendly.
author: Hannah R.

description: They serve the best curry!  Super flavorful with chunky onions. I prefer their curry over Muracci's on Kearny for the flavor and consistency.  I miss that I'm not as close as I was to their regular spot due to new job.
author: Michelle N.

description:
[NOTE: For the week of March 14th, JapaCurry is donating 10% of their sales proceeds to Japan Red Cross. Please help support this great cause.]

Apples to Apples, this gourmet food truck is great. Sure, sure, they have a limited menu, but I like that they focus on what they're good at...namely curry with fried stuff over rice.

The curry is tasty and not a typical curry sauce. It's got life to it. You can tell just by looking at it. In addition to the usual spices, there must be onions, garlic, shallots, possibly some tamarind...and lotsa love. 

The tonkatsu could benefit from another 30 seconds in the fryer but the cut of pork that they use is succulent, meaty and tender all at the same time.

PLUS, they take care to box the 6+ inches of katsu with the white rice and little plastic container of pickled radish separate from the curry. Maybe others don't care so much about that but this means more curry, plus katsu doesn't get too soggy (gets a little soggy on the underside because of the hot, fresh white rice) AND there is plenty of radish too. 

Well done, JapaCurry! Please become a permanent fixture on Sansome Street.
author: Cat T.

description: Super meh. Got a chicken katsu curry burrito at Off the Grid (Fort Mason). It cost 8 bucks and came out in about 10 minutes, so pretty decent time, but it was pretty meh. The chicken katsu was a very small portion of the burrito. Even the rice was not plentiful. The cheese was located at one small end of the burrito, and the lettuce was scant. The katsu was pretty crunchy and not over-fried, but it was nothing to write home about.
author: Danny C.

description:
Definitely a food truck to try out! 

I go to the civic center off the grid every week for the pass month since my work is right next to it. I forget cash sometimes, but I didn't last week! I waited in line and out came delicious flavorful curry! YUM! I would buy some more when they come back again! :)
author: Tina T.

description: Had a chicken katsu burrito from them @ Off The Grid @ Fort Mason, and all I have to say is I think I could eat one of these bad boys every single day and not get sick of it.
author: Derrick C.

description:
JapaCurry is addictive! i hope they come to my office area more often.
I had Katsu Curry and enjoyed. The Katsu meat was tender and crispy. mmm...i almost lick the plate.... YUM!
author: kyoko m.

description:
Lunch time in the South of Market Area/Financial District (aka SoDi or SoFA) again? Yeah, now what, Maggie? My coworker informs me of a "roach coach" located around the corner of New Montgomery and Mission. Low and behold, there was the cutesy JapaCurry truck with a line. How will I ever get my food in time to enjoy and walk back to work within a half hour? There were a few people ahead of me in line and ordering seemed to take longer than waiting to pick-up. I walked up to the counter, ordered and had my food in my hands within five minutes. Um, THAT'S IMPRESSIVE with the amount of people they serve. 

Unfortunately, they had already run out of the Chicken Katsu by the time I got there, so I settled for the Pork Katsu. The pork was tender, crispy without being oily and lightly seasoned without overpowering the star of the dish, which was supposedly the curry. The spicy curry turned out to be a little flat for me, it didn't immediately kick me in the mouth like how I normally like my spicy foods to do. The spice didn't really come through until I was halfway through my meal, which was already a little too late. I had enough curry left over to take home for myself to sop up later. Um, Fluffy. Pillowy. White Rice: perfect fluffliness for the kinda runny curry. Absolutely perfect combination. 

JapaCurry, I'll try you again if you're in my area, but I won't go out of the way for you. However, I would go out of my way to get some Volcano Curry cause well... That's another review. 

$8 for Pork Katsu Curry and they have two vegetarian options: plain veggies or veggie croquettes for $7.
author: Maggie H.

description:
My first time there today and I must say it was GOOD!!!!

I had the pork cutlet with curry. Ordered my food, waited like 2 minutes and was off to my office to eat.  It surprised me that this food truck was better than most sit-in restaurants! I am definitely planning to go again when they come back to my office area.
author: Mike C.

description:
The JapaCurry trunk was parked on front of my office today so - what choice did I have? - I had to give it a try!

Even with this convenience, I still managed to mistime it -- didnt get into line till a bit before 12:00 & ended up in line for the best part of half-an-hour. 

The menu is short -- various meats or veggie options, with rice, served with a helping of curry sauce. (There are also some "bento" options -- not sure exactly what they are...) I went for what seems to be the most popular option, Chicken Katsu on rice with Curry. Service (once you actually get to the truck) is quick and friendly. I was offered a choice of "hot" or "mild" curry sauce -- I opted for "hot", but in truth, it wasnt very spicy. So -- very simple selections -- I headed back to my desk with a take-out box of chicken & rice, and a tub of curry sauce (to be, presumably, dumped on the chicken, or alternatively, used for dunking à la Chicken McNuggets.)

The Chicken Katsu was good -- not exceptional, certainly not on a par with a Japanese restaurant dish -- but the addition of the curry (seeming to me more like an Indian curry, in taste) made for an interesting dish. A curious lunch -- but enjoyable, and it satisfied the craving I had for a tasty/meaty meal. A good once-in-a-while treat, I think...
author: donal c.

description: A+ Guys! Super delicious and tasty curry. Had the Kurobuta pork curry and the Pork Katsu plate! I cannot express how perfect everything went together. From the Semi Spice sweet curry and perfectly juicy and smokey flavor of the kurobuta pork sausage. It just worked and I loved it!! Thank you for putting out such great food! I will be coming back for some more! Cheers!
author: Joseph G.

description:
Fast. Delicious and.....from a truck.

Love that this is a Japanese-run food truck with uber fast, uber hot and uber delicious curry plates. I scarfed down the chicken katsu curry which was perfectly delicious and satisfying. My friend who had the same enjoyed ever bite just as much. Good portions and plenty curry to spare.

If this place located near by work, I'd be a regular on any given week day.
author: Deann M.

description:
Katsu curry (chicken) $8- chicken cutlets over a bed of rice. The curry sauce was in its own separate container. I don't eat spicy so I got the non spicy one and it is good! I wish there was small pieces of potatoes in the curry.

I need to try the other stuff they have.

japacurry is a welcomed sight for fanciers of curry, especially japanese curry. such curries are located only in certain areas, accessing them isn't always easy.   kudos for this roaming curry express.

locale: off the gird-civic center

menu:
-curry katsu (chicken or pork) 8
-kurobuta sausage (7.5)
-vegetable curry (7)
-vegetable croquettes.(7)
-sodas and green tea

sampling:
-chicken curry katsu, spicy
large portion of  lightly breaded sliced,  chicken breasts, not overcooked, meat juicy.  curry sauce came in a separate container so nothing gets soggy.
*choice of spicy or not curry sauce
-muracci's has a slight edge on taste (more depth). japacurry is hands down the leader in accessiblity.

temaki:
-menu limited to curries and vegetable croquetts.
-all japanese staff, curry must be legit and traditional.
-friendly, fast service (within 5 minutes)
-distinctive red food truck with designs all over.-
-line short, 5 people?
author: Victor G.

description:
ummmm....yum!!!

I LOVE Japanese curry but I couldn't find one that satisfy my taste buds for a long time, then,  I finally found it!!  It's "JapaCurry~!! "  

I had kurobuta sausage curry and chicken katsu curry and they were both delicious!
Curry is pretty rich and stuffing but you wanna eat it again very next day. Now that's something!!

There is always waiting line but it moves quickly and it definitely worth waiting!!!

I can't wait to try their curry pan too :))
author: CATE Y.

description: Their curry is always on point. It's EXTREMELY comparable to Muracci's - except their prices are a tad cheaper.
author: Emily C.

description:
Nori bento = [Asian] comfort food.  SO good.

The batter for the fishcake has shiso bits and nori flakes.  Nice touch.
author: s m.

description:
Good Curry! Visited them at Off The Grid: UN Plaza

Great marinated pieces of onion and small threads of beef. The curry was nice and thick and didn't feel grainy from curry powder. I ordered the chicken katsu curry and got spicy. The spice was a sleeper! Hit me midway. Nice.

Disappointed in presentation but I got lucky because I was the second to last person to get curry before they ran out. SCORE!

Need to hit up Muracci's again to compare, but JapaCurry ranks up there with them!
author: Karen U.

description: Love the curry. I always get the Karage spicy curry and have never been disappointed. the line can be 10-15 minutes but it's always worth the wait. Note, they only take cash so make sure you have some on you.
author: Cliff L.

description: This review is for JapaCurry truck that was on Samsome & Pine Street on Fridays. I went here with a co-worker for lunch since it was close by, oh and it was pay day and.. it was on our list of places to try. Yes, we have a list. We both ordered the Teriyaki chicken bento box. It already came pre made, but it was still warm. Even though, it still looked really good and it tasted good too. I think the chicken was a little bit on the dry side, but still edible. I think if you order something other than the bento box then it's cooked to order. This place is cash only so make sure you go to the ATM first. The workers are nice. I most likely will try it again and order something other than the bento box, I think I was just playing it on the safe side.
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description: I generally try to stay away from Japanese cuisine...such places aren't the best for vegetarians. But Japa Curry is different. Agreed, they have only like one vegetarian dish on their menu, but that's quite tasty. The curry is yummy and that pumpkin croquette is awesome!
author: Srivatsan S.

description: Had the japanese fried chicken--soggy. The last thing fried chicken should be. Also had the curry on top and honestly, the curry was nothing special despite lots of people raving about it.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
I was so happy to hear that JapaCurry had parked itself outside of my workplace today and even more entertained to hear that the owner of Harvest & Rowe asked them to move because they were taking away business. 

Luckily they didn't move too far -- I REALLY enjoyed my Pork Curry Katsu!  I had been wanting to look for good Japanese curry in the City and instead, it found me!  I'm a fan :)
author: Sarah Z.

description: Potato curry sandwich: yum! But why wouldn't it be? It's carb on carb, coated in carbs & deep-fried. Even I, the fattest vegetarian you'll ever meet, felt guilty after that one. But the pumpkin curry (Or was it potato? The menu was vague.) was just as good, and much more nutritious. The service could be a little friendlier. But I guess that's the price you pay for the privilege of eating at a popular roach coach.
author: Brian W.

description: Came here during a lunch break. Paid $8 for a decent amount of Katsu Curry (with spicy curry)! It came with a lot of rice, but its really hard to go wrong with katsu curry. I would go again!
author: Alice C.

description:
I would go back again.  What's not to like -- deep fried and spicy curry over rice.  Had the extra spicy pork katsu and it was a good kick.  HIt the spot for me today in this winter like weather in SF -- it's in the 50's dammit!  Need hot food to keep my gullet from freezing to bits. 

Didn't expect them to be better than Muracci but they came pretty darn close in taste.  I think Muracci gives more meat for the add'nl $1.50 though.
author: Anna C.

description:
Solid option if you're not expecting grab-n-go - although the line moves faster than roux through my intestines on a wintry, fiber-less day. The sauces are deep and dark, on the thick side, more so than I'm used to with the J-stuff, but that's cool. This homemade composition's more savory and in the end, does a better job of decimating my productivity post-lunch without shredding my insides. The chicken katsu was done just how I like it: not pounded into a flap akin to Joan Rivers' chesticles. It was thick enough, juicy and cooked perfectly. The rice was a bit on the soggy side and stuck to the bottom of the container, but for the brevity of my wait after ordering, I'll take that in a heartbeat. After all, I'm trying to cut down. 

Although the line looked immense, the wait time was maybe like 10 minutes. Got to watch a lot of fools walk down Mission and be total jerks to other human beings... and thus, I was a bump on the muddy bank of the mighty river Tuttonk. Total spendage: $8, cash only. Breath: horriblized.
author: Roy M.

description:
This truck should be parked in front of my house. and NOT GO ANYWHERE!.

I've tried Japanese curry in many places, but this food truck has to be the best. I tried it when i was at the fort mason center and i loved it so much, i had 2 more servings, the price is a little expensive for the amount of food you get, but i think its still pretty worth it considering how great the curry and rice are cooked.
author: Jeffrey B.

description: So for Japanese curry, the 3 main components have to be on point, the rice, Katsu, and curry. If any one of these items are off, then I feel the whole dish is off. Well, Japa curry gets these items right 99% of the time. Their rice is usually perfect, chewy and really good. The curry is a little sweet and spicy and not too dark (like stew). Their Katsu is tender inside and crispy on the outside. The pork Katsu is my go to one with extra rice. Also, if you are super hungry, get a couple of the sausages on the side then you've an Alpha meal. Great comfort food at a good price. Nothing too special, just good flavors and texture. Jay the owner, usually in the truck is awesome too. Check them out. They are usually in the FIDI area.
author: Tim S.

description:
Came here for the second time today and didn't have to deal with a line! Awesome. First time, they had a huge line and it took a while to get the food. Regardless, today's service was quick! 

They have a badgein program now that helps keep track of your frequent buyer points. It wasn't working when I was there but I'm sure it will be next time. 

Got the chicken katsu and asked to make it spicy. It was delish! The breading on the katsu was perfectly cooked and even taking my time getting back to the office, it was still crispy on the outside, moist on the inside. 

I want to come back for the kurobuta so I'll be back!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
The chicken and pork katsu over rice with spicy curry sauce.....THE BOMB!

It's simple, filling, and delicious. Great for a cold wet day at Off the Grid or something to take home and eat while watching TV....or just on the run at lunch.
author: Leo V.

description: Delicious. The meat is juicy and tender. You can get the curry spicy or not spicy. I only wish it came with some kind of vegetable, and the bento boxes are not as good as the curry items.
author: Lilian K.

description: What was I thinking giving only 4 stars last year??  I can eat this curry everyday!  LOVE LOVE LOVE for JapaCurry.  Chicken katsu curry...BOMB.  Pumpkin croquette...BOMB.  Hella friendly staff...BOMB.  I try to catch them on 1st and Howard.  Street parking is easy at that spot.  Seriously, love for how the chicken has crunch on the outside but tender on the inside.  Love for the curry sauce coming in a separate container.  Love for the flavor with just the right amount of spiciness (I get mild and it still packs a bite to it).  To me, the curry sauce is absolutely perfect.  Not too runny, not too creamy.  And you get a good amount of food for $8.  I'm stuff mcgruff right now!  Only drawback is I'm at work right now and in dire need of a nap...
author: Joe M.

description: Yes definitely a fan with JapaCurry Truck.  The food is simple comfort food for me and the service is always quick and easy - even though the lines tend to be long.  Hey success breeds long lines - worth the wait though!!  Katsu Chicken Curry Yum!!!
author: John L.

description:
excellent curry sauce, perfect balance between tenderness and crispiness of their katsu and karaage

bentos would be better if less soggy, but maybe it's unavoidable
author: Felix W.

description:
Mm, Japanese girls waiting inside a happy orange truck of food to serve you. Who can resist? They even have the signature "Herro! Can I take you order?" accent down perfect. 

I went down to their Sansome and Pine location (right in the middle of all the FiDi hubbub!) and was surprised to see not that many people waiting for their food. Then again, I went after 1pm. Luckily for me, lack of line meant that I just had to wait for pretty much two minutes to order and receive.

Now, for the actual food, I walked fifteen minutes to go back home with this baby. I would anticipate my food tasting a little soggier than most would like, but JapaCurry's pork katsu somehow retained a state of succulent crisp. Mm baby. It brought me back to my trip to Japan. It tasted exactly like the food vendors there, too - serving a yummy snack-or-meal curry dish along the way. Here, you get a medium rectangle box with the katsu and a plastic container with the curry on the side, which is really considerate of them! I normally like my katsu breaded to be really unhealthily fried and crunchy, but JapaCurry's light crisp satisfied me perfectly. The pork was amazing - though a little too cooked and chewy for my medium rare tastes, but some fat still clung to the pork which made it taste fantastic without the curry, too. The curry amount in the container was PERFECT, which is actually EXTRAORDINARY because people usually don't give you enough curry to even finish half your meal. Perhaps there was even too much curry in the container, which means you can save extra to take home and dab on your other food or leftovers! And the pickled vegetable is really nice, too - quite mild with a soft crunch, which is lovely - usually it's too intrusive.

My only complaint would be that the spicy curry isn't spicy enough, but I also have a flame resistant tongue, so.
author: Amy Y.

description: Curry had good flavor, but was too thin.  Katsu was pretty standard.   Not worth waiting in the 20 minute line, but if they weren't so crowded I'd go again.
author: Michael E.

description:
By the time we reached the JapaCurry truck, it was past 1pm, so there wasn't really a line, but a lot of the items on the menu were sold out.  Thankfully, the Tonkatsu Curry was still available.

The curry was quite delicious.  There was a complexity of different spices infused into Japanese curries giving it a lot of depth of flavor.  I really enjoyed it.  The tonkatsu was tender and tasty, and it wasn't at all greasy as katsu's sometimes can be.  The deep-fried goodness was perfectly matched by the richness of the curry and made for a very delicious meal.

Overall, I thought the food was solid. The $8 price for curry seems relatively reasonable, and even if I wouldn't call it a cheap eat, I definitely thing it's a great meal.  I would love to come back and try it again.

For more detailed review and pictures, please go to:

http://jenneeandthecity.wordpress.com/2011/07/29/katsu-curry-from-japacurry/
author: Jen N.

description:
The curry here is really good and tasty. Unfortunately, everything else that comes with the curry dish is unremarkable.

The food truck is quite popular and there is a sizable line during peak lunch hours.  Essentially, you can choose between a bento box lunch or japanese curry box lunch, all ranging in prices between $6 and $8.  

I tried the kurobuta sausage curry, while my wife had the pork katso curry.  The wait wasn't too long - less than five minutes to receive your meal from the time that you order, and you can choose between the spicy and the normal curry in terms of "hotness."  

We chose the spicy option and proceeded to down our food.  In the box came a bed of rice, some veggies, and some frankfurters.  The curry comes in a cup that your pour over the contents.  As I mentioned earlier, the curry is very tasty - a little sweet, with just the right amount of kick.  However, the veggies were overcooked, and the sausage tasted just like some oversalted hot dog franks.  The rice was decent, but it is really hard to mess up rice.

My wife's pork katso was tastier, with a nice crispy texture, but just a tad bit dry and overcooked in the inside.

So overall, the meal was filling and tasty, but a bit overpriced (in my mind) for such a simple dish.
author: Bowdoin S.

description:
A cold night at McCoppin Hub and we had the trifecta - curry (Japa), grilled cheese (Curbside), and creme brulee (CB cart).

I like that the Japa truck has a bar on the side for stand-up eating. Seems very Japanese. The veggie curry was tasty. I like how they let you mix the veggies and the rice and the sauce yourself. I hope to get a chance to try some of their other offerings sometime soon!
author: Emily M.

description:
Awesome curry goodness!  

I realize what it means to give out a 5-star but for me, this curry is as good as it gets.  Not runny and not too thick and clumpy, and with the absolute right amount of spice (use of spices, that is).  

Enjoying the chicken katsu as we speak, and they do a very fine katsu.  And since they obviously know how to make rice, that just about covers the dish!

Check it out if you haven't tried it yet (if there are any of you left!).

Now, how to answer the question below on whether or not they deliver (???)
author: John K.

description: The special bento is amazing. For $10, you get at least 6 different types of dishes. Mine had salmon, mackerel, chicken karaage, seaweed rice, salad, julienned cabbage, potato croquette, pickled vegetables, and an orange slice.
author: Michael W.

description:
There was a long line as I walked up, but it moved very fast.  Two windows were open-one for bento's and the other for everything else.  The selection was decent, but dwindled as I got closer to the truck.  Due to limited inventory, they cross items off the menu as they sell out.  Of the eight items offered, three were sold out as I got to the window-they were all bento's.

I ordered the curry tonkatsu and it was fresh and hot.  The sauce comes in a separate container which is nice because it keeps the katsu crunchy.  The spicy has some kick, just the way I like it.  $8 included tax and it was just the right amount of food (more rice than meat) for lunch, but not much variey.  Rice, tonkatsu, sauce, and a tiny pickled radish container.

Bring cash because that's the only way you'll get food.

Overall, very tasty and fresh.  If someone brought this to me, I wouldn't have known it came from a truck!
author: Curtis C.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of food trucks...at least not anymore. Overpriced food for average to above average taste. I love Japanese curry and JapaCurry definitely did not make me remember the cuisine of my homeland. Okay, okay I'm not Japanese, but comfort food should be comforting regardless of national origin. Overall, my impressions of this place are that the curry was okay relative to other Japanese curry dishes I have tried, but in terms of the quality of the food from a  food truck, this is one of the better trucks out there.

The food they serve up here is decent enough considering the portion size and price. I went with the chicken katsu over rice and with the spicy curry. All fried foods are good and it is hard to complain about the Japanese version of fried chicken. I definitely enjoyed the curry, considering I like spicy foods. If they kicked it up another spice notch, I wouldn't complain. 

If you love the food truck scene this is definitely a truck you should check out. If you love Japanese curry, this may or may not live up to your expectations. But 8 bucks for a decent and pretty filling lunch; that's not too bad. There are worse and more expensive lunch options out there.
author: Allan Y.

description: Super good kara-age curry.  Chicken was very moist and the spicy curry was delicious.
author: S L.

description:
for $8.25 you can get one of the best katsu curries in the city, with an extra side of pickles.

rice is perfect stickiness
katsu pork is juicy with just a hint of fat
curry is mild with a hint of cumin.  could be a bit spicier

delicious lunch option  and worth the trek to locate the food truck
author: Josie M.

description:
This is my favorite food truck that i have found so far.  I get the chicken katsu curry with an extra pumpkin croquette and it is amazing.  

I have been here over ten times with my girl friend and co-worker and they too love it.  It is only by me on Monday and Friday so sadly if i want it, I have to make sure and plan for it one of those days.

I would highly suggest this food truck if you want to try a little Japanese style curry.  The flavor is great and the quality of chicken is generally good white meat.  They have recently been getting more popular by be so you may have to wait a little bit depending on what time you get to the truck, but i think it is well worth it!
author: Johnny A.

description:
Luckily for me, the Japacurry truck parks right outside my office on Mission and Montgomery on Thursdays.  
First time I tried this place, I ordered the pumpkin croquette and vegetables w/ spicy curry.  Curry was awesome w/ good spiciness to it, and the veggies were breaded and fried to perfection.  However, I felt a little shortchanged because it was just 3 pieces of vegetables, the pumpin croquette, and alot of steam rice.  For $8, I was expecting my meal to be a litle more satisfying.  
I went back today, and ordered the bbq beef bento box.  But to my disappointment the bento box was prepackaged.  It was made the same day it was packaged, but would've prefered it to be made to order.  The bento box was good, but I felt it would've been better if it was made to order.  
Anyhow, the curry is the highlight of this food truck, that's why I'm giving it a well deserved 4 stars.
author: Emmett B.

description: Very good curry.  Not the Japanese out of the box stuff.  Chicken katsu was very tender.  Pickles are a plus as well.  Very cool they have the frequent card.  First day SOMA in the FIDI, smart move.  The line was long, but moved.  They will do very well if they go around the area during lunch.
author: Josh L.

description:
$8 for a pork katsu curry or $7 for a veggie is almost restaurant prices.
But....quality of the pork was good, flavor and thickness of the curry works really well with the rice. You can choose mild, spicy or extra spicy. 

I'm really impressed with how fast the line moves, so don't get turned off if you see 15 people standing there. I was probably the 8th person in line and got my food in 5 mins. 

I can't give it a 5 star becasue the bento is always sold out (which I understand since they don't make those on the truck) and I wish it is just a buck or two cheaper.....afterall, food truck should be easy on the wallet. 

Cash only .
author: Maggie C.

description: Tried this truck yesterday after multiple people had hyped it up.  Went early and hardly had to wait.  The curry was very flavorful but not as thick as I had imagined it to be... I guess I like really thick and brown japanese curry.  I got the Katsu (pork) curry and pumpkin croquette as recommended with brown rice.  I was not dissapointed.  It delivered a filling lunch.  The prices are a little steep as you could probably get the same thing at a restaurant for under $10 but here it came out to be over about $11.  I also wished they give you extra curry sauce because the a mount they give you isn't enough for the large piece of meat and tons of rice.
author: Margie C.

description:
Yummm. I have had random cravings for curry, and japacurry does not disappoint as it comes around my workplace. 

Unfortunately Muracci's is a bit far and I am unable to get my butt over there. But yes. I would recommend this on a cold day. 

I ordered the tonkatsu with spicy curry. It comes with a HUGE portion of rice, that I mostly disregarded. Curry was tasty and comforting, and I immediately felt like sleeping. The tonkatsu was breaded and fried well and went gloriously with the curry. Now if only they had pickled onions. nom nom nom :)
author: Angela H.

description:
I can't decide really if I'm a fan, but there's a lot going for it!  I came across them at the Off the Grid at City Hall on Fridays.

The folks are tres nice.  The truck is awesome & purty. Service is polite & speedy! The price is pretty good, $8 for a katsu donburi.  The oft mentioned fluffy white rice.  The perfectly breaded & cooked chicken katsu.  I had the spicy curry sauce which was very thoughtfully provided in a sealed plastic container--yay for the klutz that I am, yay for the packaging whore that I am, boo for too much packaging--(but I will reuse it).  the spice level didn't really show itself until later.  Humph.  I just can't put my finger on what I wasn't into about the curry.  I am admittedly a new fan of making my own indian curries, as well as coconut milk based thai curries and the two are completely different from japanese curry; but it felt like the curry sauce was missing it's base today.
 
This is completely fixable, and I'm betting that it was just an off day--it still was a win in my book! With all my whining, I still finished most of it, and still managed a little bit of a spice kick after eating half the sauce!

 I'll be back again someday when the lure of the Bao truck doesn't win me over as it usually does!
author: Rebecca R.

description: Their karage curry is simply amazing and they frequently run out of it, if you reach there after 1:00 pm. Make sure you bring cash.
author: Chinz C.

description: The bento boxes, it is all about the bento boxes!  The hot lunches are delicious, just tends to be very heavy.  So whenever I am able to snag one of the bento boxes before they run out, it makes me giddy and happy, like make-you-want-to-do-a-happy-food-dance kind of happy.  Why?  Because for $7 you get a tasty lunch with all sorts of goodies, a lot of them vegetables.  A bento box for lunch from the Japacurry Truck is a real treat!
author: Mirba E.

description: The vegetable croquette was savory and deee-lightful, and the curry quite tasty, but nothing special. I'm quite underwhelmed by the value. Most of the tray was weighed down by rice, and the selection of vegetables was sparse and limp. I make a better curry, and for $7, I could throw together an entire vat that would feed me for days.
author: M.C. H.

description:
I don't typically have high expectations for a food truck but JapaCurry was really good! I am not sure if their menu changes, but when I went today for lunch they had pork or chicken katsu curry, veggie curry, a sausage curry and a couple bento boxes.

It was really fast, though I think their price at $8 a dish was more than nearby Delica or Muracci's. I think it's worth the extra buck or two to not wait in the Muracci's line, and the portions are reasonable. Their spicy curry is just the regular curry with some chili powder on top, so it's not very hot but the flavor is good. My coworker got the veggie curry which had a lot of good fresh veggies like asparagus, instead of the usual mush most places serve. I wouldn't recommend the sausage curry, it just looked like bangers tossed on top of rice. It would be awesome if they had regular chicken and not just katsu.

I'll definitely come back.
author: Beth D.

description: $8 for delicious Chicken Katsu curry! There's nothing better than that. Cheap prices and great tasting food. Their menu is a bit small since they are operating out of a truck. The spicy curry doesn't taste too spicy... the difference is they put a bit more of the chili powder in it. The line on the street is a bit long since it seems to be always at least 10 people in line. The wait is about 15 minutes to get through the line. The food is already packaged for pickup once you pay the cashier lady.
author: Steven B.

description: Great Japanese food truck!  I am vegetarian, so I was very pleasantly surprised to see something on the menu other than chicken katsu and teriyaki beef.  I ordered the pumpkin croquette, which is a plump little patty made of pumpkin and potato.  It's so delicious with the curry sauce!  The order also comes with some steamed veggies as well as a couple of crispy potatos.  The rice was cooked perfectly.  I found the whole meal to be delicious, filling, and worth $8.  I was glad they had canned iced green tea too, the perfect accompaniment to my meal.  I would highly recommend that people check them out.  You know where I will be on Fridays ;)
author: Kandi K.

description:
I've ordered a lot of katsu dishes in restaurants over the years (childhood favorite), but the curry katsu I got from this little truck was possibly the best. It was the right thickness, cooked perfectly and had just the right amount of crunch without being oily. The curry is really nice, too.

Waiting til Friday (when they come back to my neighborhood) is going to be painful.

E
author: Eric K.

description:
Mmmmm, their pork katsu curry will warm your soul.  Tender breaded pork cutlets smothered with a savory Japanese curry, all over a heaping serving of rice.  Great to eat on a cold day.  

**For my full review on foodtrucks around SF, visit my blog link under my profile. Enjoy!**
author: Karin V.

description:
As a plan of attack for my first visit to Off the Grid, I did some research on the potential trucks that would be there and JapaCurry was at the top of my list.  It's not a surprise that I ordered almost everything on their menu that had not yet been sold out!  

So what did I order?

Pork katsu curry with rice - originally, I had wanted to order the chicken katsu, but as luck would have it, they sold out right as I got to the front of the line!  So, I went with the pork instead.  The portion was pretty decent, curry was NOT spicy, but still very tasty.  What I really liked was the curry to rice and pork ratio.  I would totally get this everyday if I could.

Shrimp katsu - this was basically fried shrimp on a stick with some mayo sauce on top, but eating it while it's still hot...SO good and potentially addicting!

Croquettes - The pumpkin croquettes were sold out, but I had planned to get the more traditional potato croquettes anyway.  These were REALLY yummy.  They were fried just right, had a crunchy outside and soft inside.  Although they give you tonkatsu sauce for it, I recommend dipping it in the curry.  Actually, it would be an improvement on an already very yummy item if they added curry powder to the potatoes...*drool*

All in all, I enjoyed everything I had from JapaCurry and would get more in a heartbeat.  Please come to the South Bay soon!!!  You'll have me as a loyal follower!
author: Belinda O.

description:
Good job Japa Curry! I will be back!
Please come closer to Fremont and Mission please!!
author: JC C.

description:
I tried the JapaCurry truck at off the grid at fort mason center and I must say it's worth $6 for the portion you get and the quality of the food. I was surprised to see how much you actually get. I ordered the Tonkatsu curry over rice . 

The sauce had a hint of spice but not over powering, the tonkatsu was breaded and fried to the crisp and golden brown. It was the perfect combo with a little bit of rice, curry sauce and pork all in one bite. They give you a lot of rice which is good because there was so much sauce left over after eating the tonkatsu. I could eat the sauce itself with the rice.

It's fast and easy on the go kind of food. Good for a quick lunch or a snack. $6 well spent, go try it now!
author: Elsa Y.

description:
Mmm...Japanese Curry...

Was lucky enough to find the truck on Howard last Tuesday and had a taste of their chicken katsu curry ($7) and pork katsu curry ($8).  The curry was flavorful and had just enough kick.  Both katsus were tender inside and crispy outside.  Love how they give you a little container of red fukujinzuke too.  Perfect.
author: Nina L.

description:
I had an opportunity to try this curry truck today as it was in Sunnyvale (where I work). I had the chicken katsu curry for $7. For $7 it is a very reasonable curry. As I ordered, the guy said they have regular and spicy curry, so I ordered the spicy.

The order comes in 3 containers. A square one that has the rice and Chicken Katsu. A separate small round plastic container inside the square one with fukujinzuke (the pickled vegetable), and clear plastic round 1 pint container with the curry. This was very good that they did not pour the curry over the rice, as I had a 10 minute drive back to the office. Also makes it easy to heat up the curry in the microwave if needed. Also, they must have read the review here of the woman who complained about her pickled veggies being buried underneath her rice.

So now the taste... the chicken cutlet was decent. Not dry, and tender. But, you could tell that it was pre-fried in the morning and has been sitting for a while. Not freshly fried on the truck. The katsu at Muracchi in Los Altos is still the best in my book. 

The curry, upon first bite did not seem so spicy, though I had asked for the spicy one. As mentioned by others, it seems like they cook this curry over a long time as you could tell the vegetables are almost in puree form and the vegetable flavor has been infused in the curry well. I love this style of curry. The thickness, I would put ad mid way between loose and thick.

As I made my way through my meal, the hotness started to kick in... Wow... the hotness is the type that you don't first notice, but as time goes on, it gradually comes on strong. By the end of my lunch, I had to go get a glass of water as the hotness was getting... well... pretty hot..

For a quick decent lunch at a good price, the Japacurry truck is definitely cool.
author: Takeshi S.

description:
I was really excited about JapaCurry because of all the great things I had read about it. While I thought the curry was pretty good overall, I feel like this one's mostly hype. The portions are fine, but I wish there was more meat. I got the pork katsu. I guess the last time I went out to get pork katsu was when I went to Muraccis. Thus, my heart sank when I opened the box and made that immediate comparison. Nevertheless, the meat was actually pretty good. The curry itself wasn't as impressive. I mean it was good, but it was very oily and it was seriously lacking in the vegetable sector. 

All in all, the curry was fine, but I've had better and it did not live up to the hype. Service is pretty quick though.
author: Alea G.

description:
This place is pretty good.  The curry is kinda watery but the katsu makes up for it.  Lightly breaded, crispy on the outside, juicy and tender inside.

Compared to Muracci, the curry is about the same.  I know most Japanese curry is not as thick as I'd like it but definitely prefer Japantown's "On The Bridge" curry to this truck.  But for a truck near my work in downtown SF, this is great!

Portions are a bit small.  I felt like I could eat two of them myself.
author: Philip L.

description:
JapaCurry Truck
Yumtum Belly
spicyCurry Flavor

HurryBuy JapaCurry
author: Po L.

description:
Got the fried pork curry over rice.  Bland and overpriced.  A huge portion of rice, and not much else.  Pork was cooked well, but the curry had little flavor, and was not "spicy". For $8 you could be eating katsu don at a real restaurant.  

And all the bento boxes are pre made.  Are they even trying?
author: Andrew L.

description: Chicken katsu curry is delicious and at a great price! Wait wasn't too long today at around 11:30. Definitely will go again :)
author: Vicki N.

description:
I had the sausage curry today in Santa Clara.

The prices were good, it was unbelievably quick - and the food was tasty.
